questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breast lumps?
questions.solution:
Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).

LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients with LCIS. 

Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of the primary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancer within the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it).

questions.text: Dicrotic notch is caused by _________
questions.solution:
Dicrotic notch is caused by closing of aortic valve.

The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve shuts.

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to:
questions.solution:
The given egg belongs to whipworm or Trichuris trichiura.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

Whipworms live in the large intestine and whipworm eggs are passed in the feces of infected persons. The eggs develop in the soil in 3-4 weeks and become infective to man. When these embryonated eggs containing infective larvae contaminate food or water, they can cause infections in humans. 

 

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation occurs in which of the following steps of the TCA cycle?

choices.text: Alpha keto glutarate to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Substrate level phosphorylation occurs when succinyl CoA gets converted to succinate in the TCA cycle.

Succinyl-CoA is converted to succinate by the enzyme succinate thiokinase or also called succinyl-CoA synthetase.

GTP formation takes place in this step, and hence this is the one and only example of substrate-level phosphorylation in the TCA cycle.

The GTP so formed is used for the decarboxylation of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate catalysed by PEPCK in gluconeogenesis.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about HDL is false?

choices.text: HDL act as  repository for the apo C and apo E.
Class B scavenger receptor B1 (SRB-1) is HDL receptor.

questions.solution:
HDL plays no role in LDL oxidation.

A major function of HDL is to act as a repository for the apo C and apo E required in the metabolism of chylomicrons and VLDL.

The class B scavenger receptor B1 (SRB-1) has been identified as an HDL receptor with a dual role in HDL metabolism. SRB-1 mediates the acceptance of cholesterol effluxed from the cells by HDL, which then transports it to the liver for excretion via the bile.

Related Pearl: Lipoprotein: Types, Sources and Action

Lipoproteins

Source

Action

Chylomicrons

Derived from intestinal absorption of triacylglycerol and other lipids

Carry exogenous/dietary triacylglycerol from the intestine to peripheral organs

Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)

Derived from the liver

Carry endogenous triacylglycerol from the liver to peripheral organs

Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)

Derived from VLDL

Involved in cholesterol transport

Highdensity lipoproteins (HDL)

Derived from Liver, intestine, VLDL, chylomicrons

Involved in reverse cholesterol & Phospholipids transport and also in VLDL and chylomicron metabolism

VLDL

questions.text: Which of the following fungi shows germ tube formation?
questions.solution:
Germ tube formation (also known as Reynold Braude phenomenon) is seen in Candida albicans.

This phenomena is also Seen in C. tropicalis.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37°C.

It is also positive for a relatively new characterized species, Candida dubliniensis.

questions.text:
Which of the following indices are used to determine the sex of an individual?
  1. Intermembral index
  2. Sternal index
  3. Corporobasal sacral index
  4. Ischiopubic index
  5. Cephalic index
questions.solution:
Sternal index, corporobasal sacral index, and ischiopubic index are used to determine the sex of the individual.

The intermembral index and cephalic index are helpful in determining the race of the individual.

Indices for sex determination: 

Indices Calculation (x100) Male Female
Ischiopubic index Length of pubis/Length of ischium <90 >95
Corporobasal index Transverse diameter of body of S1 / Breadth of base of sacrum 40-50 35-45
Sciatic notch index Maximum breadth of greater sciatic notch / Maximum depth of greater sciatic notch 4-5 5-6
Sacral index Transverse diameter of base of sacrum / Length of sacrum <114 >114
Sternal index Length of manubrium / Length of mesosternum 32-85 44-80

 

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

 

To determine the race of an individual -

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting. The coronary angiography revealed total blockage of the posterior descending artery. While exposing this artery during the procedure, which accompanying vessel is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The middle cardiac vein is present in the posterior interventricular groove accompanying the posterior descending artery, and hence is most likely to be injured in this case. 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: Stage of surgical anesthesia during ether administration is

choices.text: Regular respiration to cessation of breathing
Loss of consciousness to beginning of regular respiration

questions.solution:
Stages of Anesthesia:

  • Stage I (stage of analgesia or disorientation): from beginning of induction of general anesthesia to loss of consciousness.
  • Stage II (stage of excitement or delirium): from loss of consciousness to onset of automatic breathing.
  • Stage III (stage of surgical anesthesia): from onset of automatic respiration to respiratory paralysis.
  • Stage IV: from stoppage of respiration till death.

questions.text: A girl was brought to the clinic by her parents for treatment of alopecia. They gave a history of erythematous vesicular rashes that evolved into verrucous growths a few months after birth. The lesions gradually resolved and left linear pigmentation as shown below. On examination, dental dystrophy was also noted. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of incontinentia pigmenti. It is a rare X-linked dominant disorder with multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males and presents in females with skin lesions, teeth abnormalities, alopecia, nail dystrophy, and ocular and neurological findings.

The skin lesions evolve through the following characteristic stages:

  1. Vesicular
  2. Verrucous stage
  3. Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls
  4. Linear hypopigmentation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tumor suppressor gene?
questions.solution:
WT-1, RB, and P53 are all examples of tumor suppressor genes. RAS is a protein involved in signal transduction.

Tumor suppressor gene products inhibit cell proliferation. Abnormalities in these genes cause a failure to inhibit uncontrolled growth which leads to carcinogenesis. Some tumor suppressor genes and associated malignancies:

APC Inhibitor of WNT signaling Familial colonic polyps and carcinomas
NF1 Inhibitor of RAS/MAPK signaling Neurofibromatosis type 1
NF2 Cytoskeletal stability, Hippo pathway signaling Neurofibromatosis type 2 
PTEN Inhibitor of PI3K/AKT signaling Cowden syndrome
RB Inhibitor of G1/S transition during cell cycle progression Retinoblastoma
VHL Inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors Von Hippel Lindau syndrome
STK11 Suppression of cell growth when cell nutrient and energy levels are low Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
CDH1 Cell adhesion, inhibition of cell motility Gastric carcinoma
TP53 Cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage Li Fraumeni syndrome
BRCA1, BRCA2 Repair of double-stranded breaks in DNA Familial breast and ovarian carcinomas, carcinoma of male breast
MSH2, MLH1, MSH6 DNA mismatch repair Hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma
WT1 Transcription factor Wilm's tumor
MEN1 Transcription factor Multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 ( MEN1- pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreatic endocrine tumors)

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is referred to an endocrinologist with severe obesity and insatiable hunger despite adequate nutrition. Due to the early-onset severe obesity, genetic testing was done and revealed inactivating mutations in the leptin gene. Which of the following neuroendocrine abnormalities is this child most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The most prominent neuroendocrine abnormality seen in obese individuals with inactivating mutations in the leptin (ob gene) or leptin receptor (db gene) is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Leptin mutations are responsible for a rare form of obesity that runs in families. These mutations prevent leptin from delivering satiety signals. Hence, the brain perceives starvation despite adequate nutrition. It results in morbid, early-onset obesity.

Mutations in the following genes can cause obesity in humans:

  • Lep (ob)
  • LepR (db)
  • POMC
  • PC-1
  • MC4R

questions.text: The recently FDA approved drug, letermovir, is used against which virus in hematopoietic stem cell recipients?
questions.solution:
• Letermovir is used against cytomegalovirus.
  • Pharmacology:
    • Letermovir is a dihydroquinozoline that acts through the inhibition of viral terminase enzyme complex.
    • This drug is used as a prophylactic agent against cytomegalovirus (CMV) in adult CMV-seropositive, allogenic hematopoietic stem cell recipients (bone marrow transplant).
    • An added benefit of this drug is that it is active against CMV isolates that are resistant to other drugs.
  • Administration:
    • It is administered orally or intravenously, at a dose of 480 mg once per day, for 100 days post-transplant.
  • Drug interactions and adverse effects:
    • It is contraindicated with the use of pimozide, ergot alkaloids; and pitavastatin and simvastatin when co-administered with cyclosporine.
    • Adverse reactions of this drug include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, peripheral edema, cough, headache, fatigue and abdominal pain
  • Update:
    • Letermovir was approved for this usage in November 2017 by the US FDA.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented to the clinic for a missed vaccination. His routine anthropometric measurements were noted. He was found to be 90 cm tall with a lower segment of 45 cm. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism 

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Vertebral anomalies

Arm span:

  • Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span.
  • It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually<1 cm).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Viruses may contain either RNA or DNA but never both.

Some important DNA viruses include the following:

  • Herpesviridae
  • Hepadnaviridae
  • Adenoviridae

  • Only double-stranded RNA virus is Reoviridae.

questions.text: Which of the following is not expressed in the B-cell receptor complex?
questions.solution:
CD86 is a protein expressed on antigen-presenting cells, and not B-cell receptor complex. This protein provides costimulatory signals necessary for T-cell activation and survival.

B-cell receptor complex expresses the following:

  • CD79a and CD79b - essential for signal transduction through the antigen receptor
  • CD21 or CR2 - complement receptor (recognize complement products during innate immune response) and Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) receptor
  • CD40 - receives signals from helper T cells

Other B cell-associated markers are CD10 (CALLA), CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23.

questions.text: Loading dose of a drug is given____

choices.text: To achieve steady state concentration in short time
For drugs with short half life

questions.solution:
• The Loading dose is a single large dose or a few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning of treatment to attain the target plasma concentration rapidly.
  • The loading dose is required for drugs which have a high volume of distribution like chloroquine or lignocaine.
  • Attaining the target plasma concentration rapidly is essential for rapid onset of action of such drugs.
  • In the absence of loading dose, the attainment of target concentration and action is delayed because of the high volume of distribution of these drugs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is brought to the labour room in the latent phase of labor. How long will you wait till you declare her latent phase to be prolonged?
questions.solution:
Latent phase is said to be prolonged in a primigravida if it lasts for more than 20 hours.

Friedman defined prolonged latent phase as:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase

questions.text: Following spinal anesthesia, the blood pressure of a patient started dropping. Your senior asks you to administer a mixed-acting sympathomimetic. Which of the following loaded syringes will you pick?
questions.solution:
Ephedrine is a mixed-acting sympathomimetic agent which can be used to manage hypotension following spinal anesthesia.

Drugs that release norepinephrine and also directly activate receptors are called mixed-acting sympathomimetics.

Ephedrine has a dual action: 

  • Releasing agent: releases neurotransmitters from nerve endings.
  • Direct action on α1, α2, β1, and β2 receptors.

The adrenergic agents are classified into three sub-groups:

  • Directly acting agents:
    • Selective agents - phenylephrine (α1), clonidine (α2), dobutamine (β1), terbutaline (β2).
    • Non-selective agents - oxymetazoline (α1 + α2), isoproterenol (β1 + β2), epinephrine (α1 +α2 +β1 + β2) norepinephrine (α1 +α2 + β1)
  • Mixed acting agents - ephedrine (α1 +α2 +β1 + β2 + catecholamine releasing agent)
  • Indirectly acting agents:
    • Catecholamine releasing agents - amphetamine and tyramine
    • Uptake inhibitor - cocaine
    • MAO inhibitor - selegeline
    • COMT inhibitor - entacapone

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a painless loss of vision. Fundus examination reveals the lesion shown in the image. Which of the following GTP-binding proteins show point mutations in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and fundus examination are suggestive of uveal melanoma which is associated with a point mutation of GNAQ protein or GNA11 genes.

Uveal melanomas (UM) originate from melanocytes in the interior wall of the eye. This includes the iris, ciliary body, and the choroid with marked differences in light exposure (from dark anterior to illuminated posterior).

GNAS mutation causes pituitary adenoma and other endocrine tumors.

The 3 RAS genes in humans (H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer. They code for a family of proteins called GTP-binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction). When RAS is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately results in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.

Mutations in RAS genes can lead to the production of permanently activated RAS proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.

Related Pearl: Cancers associated with important oncogenes

questions.text:
Match the given patients with the intermediate host of the most likely organism causing their symptoms.
Patient Intermediate host

1. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly

A. Pig

2. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema

 B. Sandfly

3. A man with a new-onset seizure and a cyst with a dot sign in MRI brain

 C. Human

4. A woman with fever and Maltese cross appearance in peripheral smear

 D. Culex mosquito
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C (option B).

Patient Intermediate host
1. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly B. Sandfly
2. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema D. Culex mosquito
3. A man with a new-onset seizure and a cyst with a dot sign in MRI brain A. Pig
4. A woman with fever and Maltese cross appearance in peripheral smear C. Human

 

A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly is likely suffering from Kala-azar caused by Leishmania donovani. Its intermediate host is sandfly.

 

A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema is likely suffering from lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. Its intermediate host is the culex mosquito.

 

A man presenting with new-onset seizures and MRI brain showing cyst with a dot sign is likely suffering from neurocysticercosis caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs (Cysticercus cellulose). The intermediate host of Taenia solium is the pig.

 

A woman having fever with her peripheral smear showing Maltese cross appearance is likely suffering from babesiosis caused by Babesia microti. Its intermediate host is human.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination of two days duration. Presence of which of the following additional findings would make you suspect pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (pus casts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules. 

The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate.  It is found in both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specific finding.

Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.

Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth. It is seen in renal TB.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.

This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about infant larynx?

choices.text: Epiglottis is soft and omega shaped
Larynx positioned at the level of C2-C3
Supra glottis is the narrowest part

questions.solution:
Subglottis(not supraglottis) is the narrowest part of infant larynx.

Differences between larynx in infants and adults:

Feature  Infants  Adults 
Position  Opposite C2,C3  Opposite C3-C6 
Epiglottis  Large, omega shaped  Leaf shaped 
Thyroid cartilage  Flat  Angulated 
Larynx  Inverted conical or funnel shaped  Cylindrical 
Narrowest part  Subglottis  Glottis 
Submucosal tissue  More and loose  Less and dense 
Laryngeal cartilages  Soft and collapsible  Ossified and hard

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. Hence, statement 2 is correct. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period.

The image below depicts how finger-feeding is done.

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm infants (32-34 weeks) and term infants for supplementation. It can be for short or long-term use. It is a useful measure in low-medium income countries and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. The oro-motor movements are different as compared to that of breastfeeding. It is not indicated for very preterm infants.

Feeding tubes i.e. orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants (28-31 weeks) with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It is an expensive measure as it requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration with immature suck-swallow-breathe coordination.

BFHI is a global effort (sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund) to promote breastfeeding. It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding. The ten steps are attached in the pearl below.

World Breastfeeding Week is celebrated every year from 1 to 7 August to encourage breastfeeding and improve the health of babies around the world.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of mastectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common complication post-mastectomy is the development of a seroma. 

Seroma is a collection of fluid in a surgically created cavity, that results from the transection of vessels and lymphatics. It presents as a localized, well-circumscribed swelling with discomfort. The fluid is clear, yellow, and viscous.

Placement of closed suction drains that obliterate the space between the pectoralis major and skin flap is used to prevent seromas.

Other complications include:

  1. Wound infection
  2. Skin flap breakdown or necrosis
  3. Lymphedema
  4. Hemorrhage

questions.text: Patients with which of the following diseases develop features of androgen insensitivity?
questions.solution:
Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy results in androgen insensitivity. 

It is an X-linked lower motor neuron disorder caused by CAG repeats in the gene encoding the polyglutamine tracts of the androgen receptor. It presents with progressive weakness and wasting of limb and bulbar muscles and features of androgen insensitivity like gynecomastia and reduced fertility. 

Disease Pathological protein
Huntington's disease Huntington (Polyglutamine)
Spinocerebellar ataxia(SCA1, 2, 6, 7, 17 and DRPLA) Various proteins (Polyglutamine containing)
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis SOD1, TDP-43, FUS
Spinal-bulbar muscular atrophy Androgen receptor (Polyglutamine containing)

questions.text: Methyldopa is primarily used for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Methyldopa is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus.

Antihypertensives found safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs like nifedipine, amlodipine - however, they should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARB)
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside 

Labetalol is considered the first-line agent for hypertensive emergency in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following are climbing fibers?
questions.solution:
Climbing fibers are olivocerebellar fibers. They originate from the inferior olivary nucleus. 

Climbing fibers and mossy fibers are the two main excitatory inputs to the cerebellum.

Climbing fibres Mossy fibres
They come from one single source via the inferior olivary nuclei. They come from many sources and the fibers synapse with granule cells to form glomeruli.

End on single Purkinje cells.

Convey proprioceptive inputs from all over the body.

 Axons of granule cells bifurcate and form parallel fibers which excite multiple Purkinje cells.

Note: Mossy fibres provide direct input via the pontine nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match

choices.text: Durozirz’s sign – Femoral diastolic murmur as blood flows backwards in diastole
Traube’s sign – capillary pulsations in nail bed

questions.solution:
Traube's sign – Pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Peripheral signs of Aortic Regurgitation:

  • Corrigan's sign - Carotid pulsation.
  • De Musset’s sign- Head nodding.
  • Duroziez’s sign – Femoral diastolic murmur as blood flows backwards in diastole.
  • Traube’s sign – Pistol shot sound over femoral arteries.
  • Quincke’s sign – Capillary pulsations in nail beds.
  • Hill’s sign – Lower limb BP is much higher than the upper limb.

questions.text: Anika, a 6-year-old girl good at sprint events, has been avoiding her track practices over the recent few weeks. Her mother informs that she skips her classes owing to her knee pain. Her X-ray reveals subperiosteal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pseudoparalysis which is a feature of scurvy - vitamin C deficiency

The subperiosteal haemorrhages in the lower limb bones can cause acute swelling and pain; the condition might mimic acute osteomyelitis or arthritis. The child refuses to walk because of the pain; hence, it is called pseudoparalysis.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts caudal regression syndrome.

The caudal regression syndrome is a rare malformation but is frequently associated with maternal diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.

It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants.

questions.text: Cardiac CT is done in which phase?
questions.solution:
A cardiac CT is done in mid-diastole assisted by synchronous ECG gating. The least cardiac motion occurs during diastole when the ventricles are passively filling. Prospective ECG triggering uses the ECG signal to control scanning so that X-rays are generated and projection data are acquired only during cardiac diastole.

Cardiac CT is done in CAD and for coronary calcium scoring. Coronary calcium scoring denotes the degree of atherosclerosis and determines prognosis in patients with coronary artery disease.

It is an example of multi-slice CT or multidetector CT (MDCT). In MDCT multiple sections can be taken in one rotation. Spiral CT takes only one section in one rotation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and a transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which of the following is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome and gastrinoma is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 / Wermer's syndrome. 

Enteropancreatic tumors in MEN1 syndrome are:

  • Non-functioning pancreatic tumors (most common overall)
  • Functioning pancreatic tumors :
    • Gastrinoma - 50% (most common among functioning pancreatic tumours)
    • Insulinoma - 30%
    • Glucagonoma
    • VIPoma (least common)

questions.text: A man complains of bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and pinna for the last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine has turned black on standing, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with urine that turns black on standing and blackish discoloration of soft tissues (oochronosis) is characteristic of alkaptonuria. It occurs due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase). The homogentisic acid in these patients is oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-colored alkapton bodies, which deposit in soft tissues like cartilage, and this phenomenon is called ochronosis.

In the following images, A shows normal urine and B shows urine from patients with alkaptonuria

questions.text: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes _____________
questions.solution:
Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria.

Other options:

  • Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD)
  • Variegate porphyria: Deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX)
  •  X-Linked protoporphyria: Gain of function mutation of δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS2)

questions.text: What does the term 'placental sign' denote?

choices.text: Alteration of fetal heart rate on pressing the head into the pelvis
Spotting on the expected date of period in early months of pregnancy
Permanent lengthening of the cord in 3rd stage of labor
Slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labor

questions.solution:
Spotting on the expected date of menstruation in the early months of pregnancy is known as placental sign.

Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy until the decidual space is obliterated by the fusion of decidua parietalis with decidua capsularis. The bleeding is usually scanty and lasts for a shorter duration than in a regular menstrual cycle.

Option A: Slowing of the fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis is suggestive of placenta previa (especially of posterior type) and is called Stallworthy’s sign. The fetal heart rate recovers as soon as the pressure is released.

Options C and D: Permanent lengthening of the cord and slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labor are suggestive of separation of the placenta.

questions.text: False about pre-renal acute renal failure is
questions.solution:
In case of pre-renal acute renal failure, blood urea nitrogen/plasma creatinine ratio will be > 20.

Differences between pre-renal and intrinsic renal failure:

BUN/Plasma creatinine ratio >20:1 10–15:1
Urine osmolality (mosmol/L H2O) >500 <350
Urine sodium UNa (meq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium <1% >2%
Urine/plasma creatinine (UCr/PCr) >40 <20
Urinalysis (casts) None or hyaline/ granular Muddy brown

questions.solution:
The foramen marked is the foramen spinosum. The structures passing through it are:

questions.text: What is the dense zone of calcification seen at the metaphysis in scurvy?
questions.solution:
Dense zone of calcification at growing metaphysis seen in scurvy is known as Frankel's line.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: A 45 year old male comes to the psychiatry OPD and the following clinical features are noted which are seen for more than 6 months. He speaks to himself, complains of hearing two people talking about him, reduced affect and impaired judgement. What is your diagnosis
questions.solution:
Patient has 3rd person auditory hallucination, reduced affect, lack of insight, impaired judgement since > 6 months which are suggestive of schizophrenia.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM V):

  • Characteristic features – 2/ more of the following has to be present for > 1 month. And at least one must among the a, b, c
    • a. Delusion- bizzare delusion
    • b. Hallucination- third degree hallucination
    • c. Disorganised speech (or formal thought disorder)
    • d. Disorganised behaviour
    • e. Affective flattening
  • 6 months or more – duration of symptoms
  • Social dysfunction
  • Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic appearance of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian hypermature cataract is characterized by the liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile Cataract

Types:

  • Cortical (soft cataract): 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract): 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataract

  • Pigmented nuclear cataracts: Due to the deposition of urochrome pigment
    • Catarata brunescens
    • Catarata nigra
    • Catarata rubra

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia. They result in an increase in the levels of LDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides.

Option A: Thiazide reduces Ca2+ excretion and is used in the treatment of idiopathic hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis.

Option C: They are also used in the treatment of edema associated with CHF, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option D: Thiazides are the mainstay for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. They reduce the kidney's ability to excrete free water. They increase proximal tubular water absorption and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine.

questions.text: In India, the level of iodization is fixed at?

choices.text: Not less than 30 ppm at production point and not less than 15ppm at consumer level
Not less than 30 ppm at production and at consumer level
Not less than 15 ppm at production point and at consumer level
Not less than 50 ppm at production point and not less than 25 ppm at consumer

questions.solution:
In India, the level of iodization is fixed at not less than 30 ppm at production point and not less than 15 ppm at the consumer level.

  • The best source of Iodine are sea foods(sea salt, sea fish).
  • Daily requirement of Iodine for adults is 150 mcg/d.
  • Daily requirement of Iodine during pregnancy is 250 mcg/d.
  • 2 in 1 salt is common salt fortified with iron and iodine 1 ml of Iodized oil injection will give protection for 4 years.

The interference with Iodine utilization by the thyroid gland is caused by goitrogens. The brassica group of vegetables (cabbage, cauliflower) contains goitrogens. Most important dietary goitrogens are cyanoglycosides and thiocyanates.

Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive indicator of environmental iodine deficiency and thus an effective indicator for monitoring the impact of a programme.

questions.text: Type 1 thyroplasty is used for:
questions.solution:
Thyroplasty:

It is a form of phono-surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki divided thyroplasty procedures into four categories to produce functional alteration of vocal cords.

  • Type 1- Medialisation of vocal cord.
  • Type 2- Lateralisation of vocal cord to improve the airway.
  • Type 3- Shortening of vocal cord. This gives low pitch voice. Done in puberphonia and in those who have undergone transformation from female to male.
  • Type 4- Lengthening of vocal cord. This gives high pitch voice. Done in androphonia, conversion from male to female and age related laxity of vocal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hemoprotein?
questions.solution:
Cytochrome oxidase is a hemoprotein widely distributed in many tissues.

Hemoproteins are metalloproteins that have a typical heme prosthetic group. They are present in myoglobin, hemoglobin, and other cytochromes.

Cytochrome oxidase is the terminal component of the chain of respiratory carriers found in mitochondria and transfers electrons resulting from the oxidation of substrate molecules by dehydrogenases to their final acceptor, oxygen. It contains two molecules of heme, each having one Fe atom that oscillates between Fe3+ and Fe2+ during oxidation and reduction. It also contains two atoms of copper, each associated with a heme unit.

The action of the enzyme is blocked by carbon monoxide, cyanide, and hydrogen sulfide, and this causes poisoning by preventing cellular respiration.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Workshop

A. Series of lectures on a subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions
2. Symposium B. Incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, discussions, and may last for half a day to a week.
3. Role play C. Series of meetings emphasizing individual work within the group
4. Seminar

D. Dramatization of social situations for health education
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication

questions.text: An infraclavicular block was given in a patient with distal humerus fracture for open reduction and internal fixation. Which of the following branches of brachial plexus would likely be anesthetized?
questions.solution:
The thoracodorsal nerve would be anesthetized in the infraclavicular nerve block as it is an infraclavicular branch of the brachial plexus. It arises from the posterior cord (C6-C8).

Branches of the brachial plexus that arise from the roots and trunk are supraclavicular branches. They include:

  • Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)
  • Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
  • Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6)

All the other branches of the brachial plexus that arise from the cords are infraclavicular branches.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)

Ulnar nerve (C8,T1)

Medial root of median nerve (C8,T1)
Posterior cord (STARS)

Upper Subscapular nerve (C5,C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)

Axillary (C5,C6)

Radial (C5-T1)

Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

 

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus Blocks

 

Name of Block Level of Block Adequate Analgesia Seen at Limitations
Interscalene Superior and middle trunk Shoulder and upper arm. Most intense effect at C5-C7 dermatomes. Ulnar nerve (C8,T1) sparing
Supraclavicular Distal trunk and proximal division Elbow, forearm and hand Axillary and suprascapular nerve sparing; Pneumothorax, phrenic nerve palsy

questions.text: The principle that “ In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor” is known as ______
questions.solution:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law.

Laws in Sensory Physiology

  • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
  • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis?
questions.solution:
The structure most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is postcapillary venules.

Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is defined as vasculitis which is limited to the small vessels of the skin. There is no systemic vasculitis and glomerulonephritis. It most commonly affects postcapillary venules.

It is characterized by the presence of leukocytoclasis (presence of neutrophil debris in and around the blood vessels).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is Iodine induced hyperthyroidism
The superior thyroid arteries arise from the ipsilateral external carotid arteries
T3 is more physiologically active than T4
The parafollicular C cells of the thyroid are of neuroendocrine in origin

questions.solution:
Wolff- Chaikoff effect is due to iodine induced hypothyroidism. (Wolf is hypo)

  • Excessively large doses of iodide may lead to initial increased organification, followed by suppression, a phenomenon called the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.
  • It is due to inhibition of Iodine release.

Large doses of iodide given to a patient with a hyperplastic endemic goitre that is iodine avid may produce temporary hyperthyroidism and, very occasionally, persistent hyperthyroidism which is referred to as Jod -basedow effect.

  • T4 is in highest concentration in serum with relatively longer half life than T3.
  • T3 has relatively higher metabolic potency than T4.
  • 100% T4 is produced from thyroid gland but T3 is mainly produced by peripheral conversion of T4.
  • T3 fraction is higher in the intracellular compartment than T4.

 

Related Pearl: Properties of thyroid hormone

Hormone property T3 T4
Fraction of total hormone in unbound form 0.02%
Half life 1 day 7 days
Fraction directly from thyroid 20% 100%
Intracellular hormone fraction ~70% ~20%
Relative metabolic potency 1 0.3

questions.text: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery which is also known as the artery of epistaxis.

It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

1 - Anterior ethmoidal artery

2 - Posterior ethmoidal artery

4 - Greater palatine artery

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in megaloblastic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anaemia has hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophil.

The basic pathophysiology of megaloblastic anaemia is impairment of DNA synthesis. This leads to ineffective and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Peripheral smear findings are:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Marked variation in the size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis) of red cells
  • Low reticulocyte count
  • Nucleated RBC progenitors, occasionally appearing in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe

Bone marrow findings are:

  • Markedly hypercellular, as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors
  • Granulocytic precursors, which exhibit dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, which may be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • Apoptosis of most precursors in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis), leading to pancytopenia; caused by a derangement in DNA synthesis

questions.text: A woman who came with complaints of fever, myalgia, and rash at 12 weeks of gestation is found to have positive IgM titers for rubella. She is advised MTP. If the pregnancy is taken to full term, which of the following triad of complications would you expect to see in the child?

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly
Cataracts, cicatricial skin lesions, limb defects
Sensorineural hearing loss, cataract, congenital heart defects

questions.solution:
The patient has an increased risk of congenital rubella if the pregnancy is taken full term. The triad of complications that would be expected in the child include:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss: Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease: The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus

Option A: Chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications - congenital toxoplasmosis.

Option B: Sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly - congenital CMV infection.

Option C: Cataracts, cicatricial skin lesions, limb defects - congenital varicella syndrome.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a thyroid swelling underwent thyroidectomy and the histopathological examination of the specimen shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen on histopathological examination of a neck swelling in a middle-aged female suggests a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy with a female preponderance and peaking in the 3rd-5th decade.

Risk factors include radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid carcinoma. Mostly, patients are asymptomatic or they might present with a palpable thyroid nodule. It mainly metastasizes through the lymphatic route.

Comprehensive thyroid ultrasound with bilateral central and lateral neck lymph nodes mapping should be done as part of the imaging workup. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI of the neck and chest and intraluminal imaging (laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, or esophagoscopy) may be required in patients with potentially more advanced local and regional disease.

Management includes

  • ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy for a low-risk, unilateral, 1-4 cm tumor without extrathyroidal extension/ evidence of metastatic disease as well as for a tumor that is < 1 cm in size. 
  • total thyroidectomy if high risk of recurrence.

The below image shows orphan Annie eye nuclei-

Histopathological features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin  
  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcified structures within the papillae

 

Other options-

Option B: Follicular carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

 

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma shows large pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and, mixed cells. The below image shows anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: Which is the most common cardiac rhythm seen in adults experiencing sudden cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
The most common cardiac rhythm seen in adults experiencing sudden cardiac arrest is asystole, as recorded at initial contact in 45–50% of cases.

Previously VF was thought to be the common rhythm, but its incidence has now been decreasing.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: A child comes with cyanotic spells and chest Xray was as shown below; What is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum

questions.solution:
The typical radiologic configuration as shown in the anteroposterior view above is that of TOF and consists of:

  • A narrow base.
  • Concavity of the left heart border in the area usually occupied by the pulmonary artery.
  • Normal overall heart size.
  • The hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal and pointing horizontally to the left chest wall. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot (“coeur en sabot”).
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to measure vessel wall stiffness in patients suspected to have hypertension mediated end-organ damage (HMOD)?
questions.solution:
Carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV) is the gold standard for measuring large artery stiffness due to hypertension.

Long-standing hypertension can lead to structural and functional changes in arteries and target organs like the heart, brain, arteries, and kidneys. This is called hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD).

Organ Consequences Investigations

Left ventricular hypertrophy

Decreased diastolic function

ECG

Stiffening

 

Pulse wave velocity of carotid or femoral artery (gold standard)

Carotid ultrasound

Hyaline arteriosclerosis (benign hypertension)

Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis (severe hypertension)

Renal function tests

GFR
Retina Hemorrhages and cotton wool spots Fundoscopy
Brain Stroke, impaired cognition MRI

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the polymerization of ribonucleotides into a sequence complementary to the template strand of the gene?
questions.solution:
DNA-dependent RNA polymerase is the enzyme responsible for the polymerization of ribonucleotides into a sequence complementary to the template strand of the gene.

The enzyme attaches at a specific site, the promoter, on the template strand. This is followed by the initiation of RNA synthesis at the starting point, and the process continues until a termination sequence is reached.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the formation of the perineal body?
questions.solution:
The internal anal sphincter is not involved in the formation of the perineal body.

The perineal body is a fibromuscular structure present in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangle. It attaches to various muscles in the pelvis:

  • Anterior - superficial and deep transverse perinei, bulbospongiosus
  • Posterior - external anal sphincter 
  • Superior - puborectalis, pubovaginalis and the rectovaginal septum 

It is continuous with the perineal membrane and the superficial perineal fascia. In males, it continues as the perineal raphe, and in females, it is attached to the posterior commissure and the introitus. 

The following image shows the perineal body and its muscular attachments.

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiovascular change is abnormal in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• A persistent diastolic murmur is a clinical indicator of heart disease during pregnancy.
  • In most pregnant women, a systolic murmur is heard during inspiration or expiration disappeared shortly after delivery.
  • In 20 percent of pregnant women, a soft diastolic murmur was heard but only transiently.
  • In 10 percent pregnant women, continuous murmurs were heard arising from the breast vasculature.

Option a

  • As the diaphragm becomes elevated, the heart is displaced to the left and upward and rotated on its long axis, due to which it produces a larger cardiac silhouette in chest radiographs.

Option b

  • An exaggerated splitting of the 1st heart sound with increased loudness of both components is seen in pregnancy.

Option d

  • There is an increased heart rate during pregnancy and the resting pulse rate increases by approximately 10 beats/min.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.

Kasai procedure:

questions.text: The structures marked as “1” and “2” in the image below are developmentally derived from _______ and _______, respectively.
questions.solution:
The structure marked “1” is the outer annulus fibrosus and "2" is the inner nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc. They develop from the sclerotome and notochord, respectively. 

The vertebral bodies and the annulus fibrosus (peripheral part of the intervertebral disc) are derived from the mesenchymal cells of the sclerotome.

The nucleus pulposus is a remnant of the notochord. The notochord regresses entirely in the region of vertebral bodies, but it persists in the central part of the intervertebral discs as the nucleus pulposus.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you expect to see in patients with median nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
A positive pen test is seen in median nerve palsy. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis. The hand must remain flat with palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is the inability to touch the pen.

Tests used in ulnar nerve injuries include:

  • Wartenberg's sign - Due to weakness of the palmar interossei muscles and unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, there is involuntary abduction of the little finger.
  • Positive Egawa's test - Due to weakness of dorsal interossei, side to side movements of middle finger is weak.
  • Positive book test or Froment's sign - Due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.

 

  • Card test - Inability to hold a card between the fingers due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

 

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: A patient presents with the following rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows collarette scales, which are a characteristic feature of pityriasis rosea.

Collarette refers to a scale with an adherent outer border and detachable inner border. It appears like a rim around the lesion as seen below.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scales

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis versicolor

questions.text: The use of which of the following drugs is unlikely to trigger an anaphylaxis reaction in a patient?
questions.solution:
The use of fentanyl is unlikely to cause an anaphylactic reaction. True allergic reactions to opioids like fentanyl are very rare. 

The most common cause of anaphylactic reactions during anesthesia is antibiotics (especially penicillin and cephalosporin), followed by neuromuscular blockers (rocuronium).

Amino ester local anesthetics (procaine) exhibit allergic reactions due to the metabolite PABA. Sulfa drugs like sulfonamide antibiotics, furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, and captopril also exhibit allergy in surgical patients.

questions.text: Glucocorticoids act on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids act on the intracellular cytoplasmic receptors. 

They diffuse into cytosol and bind to the cytoplasmic receptors and influence nuclear changes by activation of the receptor. 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.solution:
Sofosbuvir is not an NS5A inhibitor but is an NS5B nucleoside/nucleotide polymerase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 70 year old male is diagnosed with a brain tumor arising in the white matter. The tumor appears to be rapidly expanding, gray, and poorly defined. Microscopic examination of his brain tumour is as seen below. It is determined that the patient will only survive for a few months. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme)

  • Rapidly growing tumour – WHO Grade IV
  • Pseudopalisading necrosis and vascular/endothelial cell proliferation with Glomeruloid body
  • VEGF, produced by malignant astrocytes in response to hypoxia, contributes to this distinctive vascular change
  • Gliomatosis cerebri is a diffuse glioma with extensive infiltration of multiple regions of the brain, in some cases the entire brain
  • Meningioma- Whorls, psammoma bodies
  • Oligodendroglioma- Honeycomb appearance, fried egg cells, perinuclear halo, chicken wire capillaries, calcification
  • Lymphoma- Immunosupression, EBV associated, multifocal, DLBCL most common subtype

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?

pH- 7.24

pCO2- 60 mmHg

pO2- 52 mmHg

HCO3- - 27 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is on oral contraceptives. She presented with abdominal pain for the past few days. She was evaluated and was told that she is suffering from a liver disease. Which of the following liver disease is most likely to undergo haemorrhage ?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, hepatic adenoma  is most likely to cause haemorrhage.

These are benign liver tumors seen in women aged 25 and 50 years. The lesions are solitary, well-defined, and vascular. They are usually associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill. 

They are found incidentally but can present in some cases with pain due to rupture or bleeding. They have malignant potential.

Large hepatic adenomas are at an increased risk of rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

Surgical excision is recommended if lesions are >5 cm.

Other options:

Option A: Focular nodular hyperplasia is a benign condition with an unknown etiology. It doesn't have any malignant potential and therefore there is no need for treatment or follow-up after confirming the diagnosis.

Option B: Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the primary liver malignancies. Chronic hepatitis B infection and hepatitis C are considered risk factors. The cause of death in 60 percent of cases is related to cancer while the rest is due to an underlying pathology. Surgical resection is considered a treatment in patients with preserved liver function.

Option C: Hemangiomas are the most common liver lesions and they can rupture. Diagnosis is incidental and surgical resection is needed if the patient is significantly symptomatic or there is uncertainty in diagnosis.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of methimazole in hyperthyroidism is_____
questions.solution:
• Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that acts by inhibition of thyroid peroxidase.
  • It interferes with the oxidation of iodide ion and iodotyrosyl residues resulting in decreased formation of active hormones.
  • Methimazole does not have any effect on deiodinase enzyme (options b and c).

questions.text: The level of 2,3 –DPG is decreased in______
questions.solution:
The level of 2,3–DPG is decreased in acidosis.

2,3-DPG is produced from 3-phosphoglycerate which is a product of glycolysis. Acidosis inhibits red cell glycolysis which decreases the levels of 2,3-DPG.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

↑ in 2, 3-DPG ↓ in 2, 3-DPG
  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Acclimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: A multigravida presents at 34 weeks of gestation with preterm premature rupture of membranes. On examination, the amniotic fluid is golden-colored. Which condition will you suspect here?
questions.solution:
Golden-colored amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility. This appearance is due to presence of excess bilirubin in the amniotic fluid due to hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Vasa previa
