questions.text: Oxygen-dependent killing is done through which of the following?
questions.solution:
NADPH oxidase is involved in the oxygen-dependent killing of microbes. It results in generation of reactive oxygen intermediates.

This process is called the oxidative burst. It involves the generation of H2O2, and eventually hypochlorous acid. This H2O2-MPO-halide system is the most efficient bactericidal system of neutrophils.

Carotenoids, glutathione peroxidase, and the iron-free fraction of transferrin are antioxidants or free radical scavengers that prevent oxygen-mediated injury.

questions.text:
AFP is used as a tumor marker in which of the following cancers?
  1. Yolk sac tumor
  2. Hepatoblastoma
  3. Cholangiocarcinoma
  4. Fibrolamellar HCC
  5. HCC
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not a tumor marker used to detect cholangiocarcinoma or fibrolamellar HCC.

It is produced by a variety of tumors such as:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal carcinoma).

questions.text: Prucalopride was approved in India and the U.S. FDA approved plecanatide; both in 2017. What are these drugs used for?
questions.solution:
Prucalopride:

  • Prucalopride is a selective, high-affinity 5HT4 agonist
  • It was approved for usage in India in 2017 for chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC) to provide relief in case of laxative failure
  • It improves colonic transit and stool frequency
  • Side effects include headache, nausea and diarrhea
  • It is yet to gain approval in the United States but has in Europe

Plecantide:

  • Plecanatide is a guanylate cyclase-C agonist that is indicated for adults with CIC.
  • The recommended dose in 3mg, orally, once daily.
  • Adverse reactions include diarrhea and consequent dehydration.
  • It was approved for usage in the United States in 2017.

questions.text: Dead space is increased in all except:
questions.solution:
Dead space is increased in all except artificial airway. Dead space is the volume of a breath that does not participate in gas exchange. It is ventilation without perfusion.

  • Total dead space (Physiological dead space) = Anatomical dead space+ alveolar dead space.
  • Anatomical dead space is the area in the tracheobronchial tree where the gaseous exchange between the lung and capillaries doesn’t take place. It includes nasal cavity, larynx, trachea, bronchi, end of the terminal bronchiole.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas within unperfused alveoli (and thus not participating in gas exchange either)

 

 

Factors affecting dead space:

  • Posture:

         Upright - Increase

         Supine - Decrease

  • Position of Airway:

         Neck Extension - Increase

         Neck Flexion - Decrease

  • Others:

        Age - Increase

        Artificial airway - Decrease

        Positive pressure ventilation - Increase

        Drug anti-cholinergic - Increase

  • Pulmonary perfusion:

        Pulmonary embolism - Increase

        Hypotension - Increase

  • Pulmonary vascular disease:

        Emphysema - Increase

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presented with chest pain and fatigue. The chest radiograph is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows calcified pericardium, called an egg-in-cup appearance. It is typically seen in constrictive pericarditis.

In constrictive pericarditis, there is fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the anterior and lateral pericardium that prevents normal diastolic filling of the heart. The resulting diastolic dysfunction leads to features of right heart failure. The thickness of the pericardium is best assessed on MRI.

Note: The egg-in-cup (or ball-on-tee) appearance is also a urographic finding seen in renal papillary necrosis. 

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in cardiology

Constrictive pericarditis

questions.text: Anterograde amnesia is seen in:
questions.solution:
Anterograde amnesia is an early feature of Alzheimer’s disease. Retrograde amnesia is a sign on head injury, stroke. Spinal cord disease does not cause amnesia.

Clinical features of Alzheimer’s disease.

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighbourhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with progressive decline

Late findings:

  • Psych symptoms: hallucination
  • Dyspraxia: difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non cognitive neurologic deficits: pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • Urinary incontinence

questions.text: A known case of seizure disorder has been on long-term phenytoin therapy. Which of the following statements about this drug would be incorrect?

choices.text: Metabolism follows only zero order kinetics
Metabolized extensively by the CYP enzymes in the liver

questions.solution:
Phenytoin follows first-order kinetics at lower concentrations and as the concentration increases, the elimination changes to zero-order kinetics. The rate of elimination of phenytoin varies with the serum concentration.

As the blood levels rise, the maximal capacity of the liver to metabolize phenytoin is reached. Thus even a small increase in the dosage can result in disproportionally high plasma levels. Therefore, it requires therapeutic drug monitoring. 

About 90% of phenytoin is bound to plasma proteins, mainly albumin. Phenytoin is metabolized by the CYP enzymes in the liver.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture
questions.solution:
• Legionella pneumophilia has fastidious growth requirements and hence grows on complex media such as BYCE - Buffered Charcoal, Yeast extract agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements.
  • It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

Composition of BCYE Agar and functions of each ingredient

  1. Agar
  2. ACES buffer: ACES buffer is added to maintain the proper pH for optimal growth.
  3. Yeast extract: Yeast extract supplies the protein and other nutrients necessary to support growth
  4. Charcoal: Activated charcoal decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a metabolic product toxic to Legionella species, and may also collect carbon dioxide and modify surface tension
  5. L-Cysteine: L-Cysteine is an essential amino acid, incorporated to satisfy specific nutritional requirements of Legionella species
  6. Ferric Pyrophosphate: used as an Iron supplement; iron source
  7. Ketoglutarate monopotassium salt: Alpha-ketoglutarate is added to stimulate growth

The image below shows growth of legionella on BYCE medium

Note: BYCE has also been used for the recovery of Acanthamoeba keratitis

questions.text:
Mesangial deposits are seen in which of the following conditions?
  1. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  2. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  3. Alport syndrome
  4. Berger disease
  5. Membranous nephropathy
questions.solution:
Mesangial deposits are seen in the following conditions:

  • IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)
  • Henoch–Schonlein purpura
  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis classes I and II
  • Resolving postinfectious  glomerulonephritis

Related Pearl: Sites of Deposits in Glomerular diseases

Subepithelial
  • Membranous nephropathy (epimembranous)
  • PSGN
Intramembranous
  • Dense deposit disease (MPGN type II)
Subendothelial
  • MPGN Type I
  • Lupus nephritis class III and IV
Mesangial
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch–Schonlein Purpura
  • RPGN 
  • Lupus nephritis classes I and II
  • Resolving postinfectious  glomerulonephritis
No deposits
  • Minimal change disease
  • FSGS
  • Alport syndrome

MPGN: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

PSGN: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis 

FSGS: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication to skip the next dose in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia taking MgSO4 prophylactically?
questions.solution:
Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present.

The next dose of MgSO4 is only given when all signs of magnesium toxicity are absent.

Signs of magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)
  • Urine output <30 ml/hr
  • Chest pain, heart block

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Which of the following patients can be intubated using succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine can be administered in liver disease.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a rapid onset of action and an ultra-short duration of action. It stimulates cholinergic receptors at the neuromuscular junction and muscarinic autonomic sites. The ultrashort duration of action is because it gets rapidly hydrolyzed by butyrylcholinesterase. A decreased concentration of butyrylcholinesterase will prolong the blockade produced by succinylcholine.

In liver disease, the amount of butyrylcholinesterase will decrease (20% of normal), leading to prolonged neuromuscular blockade, but it is not a major concern in clinical practice.

Succinylcholine chloride is used to facilitate tracheal intubation. It provides skeletal muscle relaxation during surgery or mechanical ventilation.

Succinylcholine is contraindicated in: 

  • Burns patients
  • Muscle dystrophies (like Duchenne muscular dystrophy)
  • Known hypersensitivity
  • Multiple trauma, head injury

Related Pearl: Conditions causing susceptibility to succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia

The conditions that predispose to hyperkalemia following succinylcholine administration are:

  • Burn injury
  • Massive trauma, head and spinal cord injury
  • Severe intra-abdominal infection
  • Encephalitis, tetanus and stroke
  • Neuropathy like Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Severe Parkinson’s disease
  • Prolonged total body immobilization
  • Hemorrhagic shock with metabolic acidosis
  • Myopathies (eg, Duchenne’s dystrophy)

So, the use of succinylcholine is relatively contraindicated in patients having these conditions.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is glove and stocking hypostasis most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Glove and stocking hypostasis indicates postmortem staining of legs, feet, hands, and forearm. This occurs in the vertical suspension of the body as in hanging where these parts form the dependant parts.

Sites of postmortem hypostasis depending on the position of the body:

Position of the body Sites of hypostasis
Supine Back except for shoulder blades, buttocks, and calves (contact pallor)
Vertical as in hanging Legs, feet, forearm, and hands (glove and stock hypostasis)
Drowning Face, the upper part of chest, hands, lower arms
Inverted like in drunken persons Head and neck

questions.text: Diffusion capacity of Carbon monoxide is elevated in all except:
questions.solution:
DLCO decreases in pulmonary hypertension.

  • The test is performed by using a small and safe amount of carbon monoxide (CO) and measuring the gas exchange which occurs across the alveolar membrane during a 10-sec breath hold (single breath).
  • CO in exhaled breath is analyzed to determine the quantity of CO crossing the alveolar membrane and combining with hemoglobin in red blood cells.

The “single-breath diffusing capacity” (Dlco) value

  • Increases with the surface area available for diffusion and the amount of hemoglobin within the capillaries.
  • Varies inversely with alveolar membrane thickness.

The table below shows the conditions associated with decreased or increased DLCO and the mechanism of the disease:

DLCO decreases DLCO increases
  • Thicken or destroy alveolar membranes (pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema)
  • Curtail the pulmonary vasculature (pulmonary hypertension)
  • Reduce alveolar capillary hemoglobin (anemia)
  • Drugs (Amiodarone, Bleomycin, Methotrexate)
  • Interstitial Lung Disease
  • Acute Congestive Heart Failure
  • Asthma
  • Polycythemia
  • Pulmonary Hemorrhage

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman died in the hospital 3 days after she was admitted with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness of her body, along with slurring of speech. An autopsy showed the following finding in the brain. What is this pathological change in this lesion?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a stroke, which results in ischemic injury to the brain. This results in liquefactive necrosis.

Liquefactive necrosis refers to cell death by enzymatic degradation. The brain contains microglial cells, which contain many enzymes. When these cells are broken down, they release these enzymes, resulting in liquefactive necrosis.

The various types of necrosis are as follows:

Type Example
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis

Abscesses

Brain infarct

Wet gangrene
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast
Fibrinoid necrosis

Vasculitis

Aschoff bodies

Malignant hypertension

questions.text: The cross-bridges of the sarcomere in skeletal muscle are made up of _______.
questions.solution:
When the action potential reaches the muscle fiber, there is influx of Ca2+ ions. This  Ca2+ binds to troponin C and tropomyosin is moved out of the way. Myosin heads can now bind to actin and form so-called cross-bridges.

When a head attaches to an active site, this attachment simultaneously causes profound changes in the intramolecular forces between the head and arm of its cross-bridge. This causes the head to tilt toward the arm and to drag the actin filament along with it. This tilt of the head is called the power stroke. 

Immediately after tilting, the head then automatically breaks away from the active site.

Formation of cross-bridges is associated with hydrolysis of ATP and generation of force.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with meningococcal meningitis. He has a history of recurrent bacterial chest and ear infections. Family history reveals that he has a male cousin (maternal side) who died in infancy from infection. The physician suspects X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is caused by a mutation of the BTK gene
Both humoral and cell mediated immunity are affected
All classes of immunoglobulin levels are reduced
Lymph node biopsy shows depletion of follicles

questions.solution:
X-linked or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is primarily a disease of humoral immunity. Cell-mediated immunity is not affected.

It is an inherited immunodeficiency disease caused by mutations in the gene coding for Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK). B cells do not differentiate and mature. They are arrested in the pre-B cell stage.

There are extremely low IgG levels (below 100 mg/dL) and an absence of other immunoglobulin classes. The tonsils and lymph nodes are usually atrophic. Lymph node biopsy reveals depletion of cells of B cell-dependent areas (follicles). Babies born with this disorder have virtually no peripheral B cells (<1%) and suffer from recurrent bacterial infections.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph of the patient's pelvis following a road traffic accident reveals upward and lateral dislocation of the left femoral head, accompanied by an obscured lesser trochanter, indicating a posterior dislocation of the left hip.

Posterior hip dislocation is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity of the lower limb.

Radiological findings:

  • Loss of continuity of acetabulum with the femoral head (break in Shenton's line)
  • Upward and lateral displacement of the femoral head
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

The image below shows posterior dislocation with disruption of Shenton's line:

Treatment:

An early reduction should be done as the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis increases with time. 

Closed reduction under sedation or general anaesthesia is done in most cases. If there is an associated femoral neck fracture, a closed reduction should not be attempted as it can lead to the displacement of the femoral neck and disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head.

In closed reduction the following steps are done:

The pelvis is kept in a steady position and traction is applied in line of the femur with the knee flexed at 90 degrees. The hip is then flexed maintaining the traction along with internal rotation and adduction. This is called Allis' maneuver. The below image describes this technique: 

 Other methods of closed reduction include - Stimson's maneuver, East Baltimore lift maneuver, and Bigelow's maneuver. 

 

After reduction, the stability of the hip is tested by flexing the hip to 90 degrees, and a longitudinal and posteriorly directed force is applied. While performing this the joint is monitored in an image intensifier to look for any signs of subluxation. In case of evidence of subluxation or any significant fractures then surgical repair should be done. If there is a delay in surgical correction, skeletal traction with a distal femoral traction pin can be done.

If there is damage to the acetabulum, or intervening structures between the femoral head and the acetabular surface are present - open reduction can be considered. 

Early complications:

  • Sciatic nerve injury - It can be damaged in 10-20% of the cases
  • Vascular injury - Superior gluteal artery tear can occur
  • Concurrent femoral shaft fracture - When both occur together hip dislocation may be missed

Late complications:

  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Myositis ossificans 
  • Secondary osteoarthritis 
  • Recurrent instability

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: In a patient with suspected CSF rhinorrhea, the presence of which of the following in the nasal discharge will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of β 2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the specimen.

β 2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus.

Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph.

Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with blood.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient came with rapidly increasing power of glasses and cylindrical glasses. The topography revealed bow tie pattern. What's the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Keratoconus presents with features of rapidly changing power of the glasses.

Keratoconus:

Clinical Presentation:

  • Young male with constantly changing power of glasses with myopia & high cylinder due to myopic astigmatism.
  • Corneal topography shows Asymmetric bow tie pattern with skewed radial axis.

Morphological pattern (3 types):

  • Nipple cone (<5mm)
  • Oval cone (5-6mm)
  • Globus cone (>6mm)

Signs:

  • Munson sign
  • Enlarged corneal nerves
  • Oil droplet reflex
  • Rizutti sign (conical reflecton on nasal cornea when a penlight is shone from the temporal side)
  • Acute Hydrops (percolation of aqueous into stroma through breaks in DM)
  • Fleischer ring (at keratoconus base, a brownish ring, probably due to haemosiderin, may form in the epithelium encircling the cone)
  • Scissor reflex on retinoscopy
  • Vogt striae in slit lamp

Important associations:

  • Marfans, Down’s, EDS syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, MVP
  • RP, Leber congenital amurosis
  • VKC, aniridia, ectopia lentis

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry:
    • Steep cornea
    • Bow tie pattern
    • Paracentral thinning of cornea (thinnest point)

KISA index is used to classify Keratoconus.

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Contact lens can be used include:
    • Rigid Gas Permeable
    • Rose K lenses
    • Soper lenses
  • Corneal collagen cross linking with Riboflavin
  • Intacs
  • Surgery
Surgery  Extent of involvement of cornea 

Deep Anterior Lamellar

Keratoplasty (DALK) 

 Upto 2/3rd of stroma is involved. 

Anterior Lamellar

Therapeutic

Keratoplasty(ALTK) 

 upto ½ of stroma is involved 

Penetrating

 Keratoplasty 

 When full thickness of cornea is involved as in acute hydrops with scar whole cornea is replaced

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has a central lytic lesion in the upper end of the humerus without any periosteal reaction. The most probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
Points in favour of simple bone cyst

  • Simple bone cyst presents most commonly in the first two decades.
  • It is due to the defect in the metaphyseal remodeling which blocks the drainage of interstitial fluid. This leads to increased pressure which leads to focal bone necrosis and accumulation of fluid.
  • Most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis.
  • On radiology, a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen.
  • No periosteal reaction is seen unless there is a fracture.

An aneurysmal Bone cyst is eccentric in location.

Ewing’s sarcoma is a diaphyseal lesion and more common in the femur.

Osteoid osteoma on radiograph shows the presence of radiolucent nidus in the cortex.

questions.text: In a double blind trial:

choices.text: Both observer and group being observed are blinded
Both observer and analyser are blinded
The group, observer and analyser are all blinded

questions.solution:
Blinding is done to reduce bias and other problems that may arise during studies, especially in RCTs.

Types:

  • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
  • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
  • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.

The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old multiparous woman presented at 32 weeks of gestation with complaints of recurrent painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, fundal height corresponded to gestational age and fetal heart rate was 140 bpm. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa. Pre-eclampsia is a risk factor for abruptio placenta, not placenta previa.

Painless bleeding PV, fundal height proportional to gestational age and presence of FHS are the differentiating features of placenta previa from abruptio placenta.

Risk factors for placenta previa are:

  • Demographic factors
    • Maternal age >35 years
    • Multiparity
    • Cigarette smoking
  • Clinical factors
    • Prior caesarean section
    • Past history of placenta previa
    • Artificial reproductive technology
    • Multifetal pregnancy
    • Succenturiate lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following glycogen storage diseases is also a lysosomal storage disorder?
questions.solution:
Pompe’s disease is the glycogen storage disease (GSD), which is also a lysosomal storage disorder.

A small amount of glycogen is degraded by the lysosomal enzyme, α (1→4)-glucosidase also known as acid maltase. A deficiency of this enzyme causes the accumulation of glycogen in vacuoles in the lysosomes. This is called type II GSD or Pompe’s disease.

Glycogen storage disorders that are associated with the following findings:

  • Liver cirrhosis: Types III, IV, IX GSD
  • Renal dysfunction: Type I GSD
  • Neurologic involvement: Type II GSD

Note: Another GSD that is also a lysosomal storage disorder is Danon disease (or glycogen storage disease Type IIb)

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman's body was retrieved from a manhole. You are suspecting antemortem drowning. Which of the following signs will most likely support your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm is an important sign of antemortem drowning. It manifests as closed hands with firmly grasped weed, grass, sticks, etc. floating in the water. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

The image given below shows a cadaveric spasm of hand, holding grass, as seen in antemortem drowning.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

questions.text: While applying the Chi-square test to a contingency table of 4 rows and 4 columns, what would the degree of freedom be in this case?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, df = (4 – 1) (4 – 1) = 9.

In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: Which of the following causes relaxation of the mesangial cells?
questions.solution:
cAMP causes relaxation of the mesangial cells. The other agents mentioned in the options cause contraction of the mesangial cells.

Agents causing relaxation of mesangial cells (mnemonic - DAnCE)

  • Dopamine
  • ANP
  • cAMP
  • PGE2

Angiotensin II is an important regulator of mesangial contraction, and there are angiotensin II receptors in the glomeruli.

Related Pearl: Agents causing contraction or relaxation of mesangial cells

Contraction of mesangial cells:

  • Endothelins
  • Angiotensin II
  • Vasopressin
  • Norepinephrine
  • Platelet-activating factor
  • Platelet-derived growth factor
  • Thromboxane A2
  • PGF2
  • Leukotrienes C4 and D4
  • Histamine

Relaxation of mesangial cells:

  • ANP
  • Dopamine
  • PGE2
  • cAMP

questions.text: A person was walking home from his work when suddenly a robber attacked him. They both started fighting and the robber held him from behind as shown in the image. During this, the victim lost his life due to difficulty in breathing. What is this type of strangulation known as?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the given image is mugging.

The term strictly means throttling by pressure from an arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm.

Note: The original meaning of ‘mugging’ has now been confused by its application, especially in North America, to any form of robbery with violence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Alvarado scoring is used in acute appendicitis, not acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: Which of the following determines the carrying capacity of a population?
questions.solution: The carrying capacity is the number of individuals of a population that can be supported for a period of time given the resources of that area. Thus, the carrying capacity is determined by the limiting resources of an area.

questions.text: Which agency of the UN has the following logo?
questions.solution:
United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) works closely with the WHO on health matters.

UNICEF’s content of services include:

  • Child health
  • Child nutrition
  • Family and child welfare
  • Education: formal and non-formal

UNICEF participates in Urban Basic Services (UBS) with aim to promote basic services like nutrition, water supply and sanitation.

UNDP is the United Nations Development Programme. It gives funds for technical assistance. Its logo:

Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) helps nations to improve living standards by mainly influencing nutrition, farming and forestry. Its logo:

United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) mainly works in the area of family health and welfare. Its logo:

questions.text: Which of the following sensory deficits is severely affected in a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Loss of proprioception is severe in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).

GBS affects the large sensory fibers, leading to attenuation or loss of deep tendon reflexes and loss of proprioception.

Cutaneous sensory deficits (e.g., loss of pain and temperature sensation) are usually relatively mild.

questions.text: A medical student is visiting her grandmother, who is recovering from heart surgery. She decides to cheer her up by painting her nails. She notices that her nails look odd as seen below. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
This image shows Beau’s lines which are generalized transverse grooves on the nail which may be full or partial thickness. They usually occur a few weeks after a precipitating systemic event like MI, measles, mumps, or pneumonia. 

Isolated transverse grooves in individual nails may occur due to trauma, inflammation, or neurological events.

Option B: Mees or Aldrich–Mees lines or Leukonychia striata are white lines that occur as a 1–2 mm wide transverse band is in the arcuate form of the lunula. They are associated with arsenic and lithium poisoning as well as renal failure.

Option C: Lindsay nails or half-and-half nails are a rare finding where the proximal portion of the nail is white and the distal half is pink, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. They are specific for renal failure.

Option D: Trachyonychia is roughening of nails observed in alopecia areata.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

Nail finding

 Associated systemic condition

Clubbing
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)
  • Mesothelioma
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congenital heart disease, Endocarditis

Koilonychia

Iron-deficiency anemia, hemochromatosis, Raynaud’s disease

Onycholysis

Psoriasis, onychomycosis, hyperthyroidism, sarcoidosis, trauma, amyloidosis

Pitting

Psoriasis, Reiter’s syndrome, Alopecia areata

Beau’s lines

Any severe systemic illness that disrupts nail growth, Raynaud’s disease, pemphigus, trauma

Yellow nail

Lymphedema, pleural effusion, immunodeficiency, bronchiectasis, sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, nephrotic syndrome, thyroiditis, tuberculosis, Raynaud’s disease

Nail Pterygium

Dorsal: Lichen Planus

Ventral: trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus

Hepatic failure, cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, CHF, hyperthyroidism, malnutrition

Telangiectasia

Rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, dermatomyositis, scleroderma

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies are not seen in phaeochromocytomas

Psammoma bodies are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by

  1. Infarction and calcification of papillae tips
  2. Calcification of intralymphatic tumor thrombi

Psammoma bodies in Tumors:

  1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  2. Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  3. Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
  4. Endometrial adenocarcinoma (Papillary Serous Carcinoma)
  5. Meningiomas
  6. Mesothelioma
  7. Somatostatinoma
  8. Prolactinoma

Psammoma bodies in Benign Conditions:

  1. Endosalpingiosis
  2. Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
  3. Melanocytic nevus

Psammoma body: a product of dystrophic calcification or of a biologically active process that aims at limiting the growth and spread of a tumor.

Psammoma bodies, H and E stain.

questions.text: You decide to administer morphine for analgesia in your patients. In which of the following patients would you avoid morphine?

choices.text: A 50 year old man with hypotension
A 32 year old woman with head injury
A 44 year old woman with hypothyroidism
A 21 year old man with type 1 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
Morphine should be avoided in a patient with head injury because:

  • Morphine retains CO2 that increases intracranial pressure (ICP) and adds to the already increased ICP.
  • Therapeutic doses can result in marked respiratory depression.
  • Interferes with the assessment of progress by causing miosis, vomiting, and altered mentation.

Among the above options, head injury seems to be the most appropriate answer and some authorities consider head injury as a contraindication. 

Option A: Hypotension can increase the susceptibility to vasodilating effects of morphine. Caution needs to be exercised.

Option C: Sensitivity to opioids is increased in hypothyroidism. Caution needs to be exercised.

Option D: Diabetes is not a contraindication for morphine use.

questions.text: Chicken wire calcification is associated with _____
questions.solution:
• Microscopically chondroblastoma consists of sheet of chondroblasts embedded in chondroid matrix.
  • The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cell giving the appearance of ‘Chicken wire.’
  • Chicken wire pattern of vascularity is seen in oligodendroglioma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady met with a car accident 2 months ago, following which she complains of screaming and waking up in the night after having nightmares of the same incident over and over again. Which of the following conditions is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder. PTSD is a psychiatric disorder occurring after a life-threatening or potentially fatal event, (e.g., war, house fire, serious accident, rape, robbery) affecting the patient or the patient’s close friend or relative.

Symptoms can be divided into four types:

  • Re-experiencing (e.g., intrusive memories of the event [flashbacks] and nightmares)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, increased startle response, impaired sleep, hypervigilance)
  • Negative cognition (e.g., negative beliefs, emotional numbing)
  • Avoidance (e.g., avoiding stimuli associated with the traumatic event)

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and reprocessing.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive

questions.text: The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by___.
questions.solution:
The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by Left stellate ganglion.

Innervation of SA Node and AV Node:

The SA node develops from structures on the right side of the embryo and the AV node from structures on the left.Therefore -

ANS

SA node

AV node

Parasympathetic

Right vagus

Left vagus

Sympathetic

Right stellate ganglion

Left stellate ganglion

questions.text: A multiparous woman at term presents to the labour room with bleeding per vaginum and ruptured membranes. NST shows fetal distress and sinusoidal heart rate pattern. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Rapid induction and delivery by vacuum
Rapid induction and delivery by forceps
Adopt Vagos method and rapid vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vasa previa since bleeding is associated with fetal distress and sinusoidal pattern in NST. Actively bleeding vasa previa in a term gestation is managed by immediate LSCS.

Sinusoidal pattern in CTG is a regular, smooth, undulating signal resembling a sine wave. It can be seen in conditions associated with severe fetal anemia like: 

  1. Anti-D allo-immunisation
  2. Fetal-maternal haemorrhage
  3. Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
  4. Ruptured vasa previa
  5. Acute fetal hypoxia
  6. Infection
  7. Cardiac malformations
  8. Hydrocephalus
  9. Gastroschisis

Sinusoidal pattern on CTG:

Management of vasa previa:

  • No bleeding
    • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids
    • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance
    • ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section
  • Bleeding present
    • Emergency caesarean section

Note: Vagos method is used in the management of umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.text: Chalazion of lid is_____
questions.solution:
The Chalazion is chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of Meibomian gland.

  • Presents as painless swelling of eye lid
  • Treatment
    • Incision and curettage
    • Intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate

questions.text: Identify this congenital anomaly found on the MRI image of a neonate.
questions.solution:
The given axial T1 weighted image demonstrates the typical figure of eight sign consistent in a neonate with lissencephaly. This disorder results from defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th and 14th weeks of gestation, leading to a poor development or absence of gyri and sulci, thickened cortex, and shallow, widened Sylvian fissures, contributing to the above radiographic appearance. Other associated anomalies may include agenesis or hypoplasia of the corpus callosum or septum pellucidum. 

The following image shows the figure of eight sign of lissencephaly:

Other options:

Option A: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and inadequate induction of forebrain structures. The pancake brain sign represents the appearance of the cerebral parenchyma in the case of alobar holoprosencephaly.

Option C: Schizencephaly is the presence of unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres due to an abnormality of morphogenesis. 

Option D: Porencephaly is an extremely rare cephalic disorder involving encephalomalacia. It is a neurological disorder of the central nervous system characterized by cysts or cavities within the cerebral hemisphere.

questions.text: A 1-day-old newborn developed severe sepsis and died after 1 day despite aggressive treatment. On examination, multiple granulomas are present over the skin. The organism isolated from the blood sample shows the motility depicted below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Early onset sepsis with skin granulomas and organisms showing tumbling motility points to a diagnosis of granulomatosis infantiseptica caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

Listeria monocytogenes shows slow tumbling motility when grown at 25 °C. But at 37°C, it is non-motile because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C. This is known as differential motility as motility pattern changes with a change in temperature. Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.

Listeria infection can manifest as febrile gastroenteritis, bacteremia, neurolisteriosis and granulomatosis infantiseptica.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: Gene for hereditary pancreatitis is located in
questions.solution:
• Mutations in Codon 29 and 122 of chromosome 7 causes autosomal dominant form of hereditary pancreatitis.
  • Gene responsible-  Cationic trypsinogen

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease has multiple skip lesions in the intestine. Surgical resection of damaged areas is being planned. Removal of which part will cause steatorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ileal resection may lead to steatorrhoea.

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption that presents with steatorrhea.

The efficiency of water absorption in the jejunum is 44% and in the is ileum 70%. Resection of ileum causes reduced conservation of fluid. Loss of bile salts into the colon affects colonic mucosa, causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. 

Small bowel motility is three times slower in the ileum than in the jejunum. In addition, the ileocaecal valve may slow the transit. Resection of the ileum results in a significant enhancement of gastric motility and acceleration of intestinal transit.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who presented with a painful swelling in the lower end of his left thigh is suspected to have osteosarcoma. Which of the following investigations is not required to evaluate his condition?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow biopsy is not performed for the evaluation of a patient of osteosarcoma. However, a bone biopsy is done for confirmation of the diagnosis by histopathology.

An MRI of the involved bone is always done for the evaluation of an osteosarcoma. It shows the extent of the tumour. A bone scan is useful for detecting skeletal metastases.

An osteosarcoma can metastasise to the lungs as well so a chest CT may be done. It is a sensitive detector of lung metastases but chest X-rays are done more commonly.

questions.text: What is the normal value of y/x in the following representation?
questions.solution:
In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4. 

It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis:

Late; scanty sputum
