questions.text: Modified BPS consists of ?
questions.solution:
Modified Biophysical Score:

Only 2 parameters are included in biophysical score that are NST and AFI. 

Biophysical score(BPS)/ Manning score:

  • It consists of 5 variables.
  • Parameters are observed for a period of  30 mins.
  • Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and minimum score of 0.
  • So the total maximum score will be 10.
Parameter Normal criteria of score 2
Non stress test Reactive pattern
Fetal breathing movements ≥1 episode lasting  > 30 second
Gross body movements ≥3 discrete body/limb movements
Fetal muscle tone ≥1 episode of active extension (limb or trunk) with return of flexion; opening and closing of hand, considered normal
Amniotic fluid ≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 × 2 cm pocket)
Score Interpretation
8- 10 Normal
6-7 Equivocal
≤5 Abnormal-  suspect asphyxia

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017?

choices.text: Advance directive rights of the mentally ill
Procedure for admission, treatment and discharge of the mentally ill

questions.solution:
Establishing mobile mental health camps for the benefit of mentally ill patients is not included under the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017.

This act encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country as well as reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support for those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and protect their rights.

The provisions of this act include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directives to allow mentally ill people to make decisions about their treatment 
  • Procedures for admission, treatment (behavioral and interpersonal therapy, medications), and discharge 
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anesthesia is used

The act also has clear instructions for the central and state mental health authorities and other mental health establishments on their endeavors.

questions.text: In testicular feminization syndrome:
questions.solution:
Testicular feminization syndrome is associated with normal breast development.

Testicular feminization syndrome:

  • The condition is inherited as a X-linked recessive gene.
  • The underlying pathology is the inability of the end organs to respond to androgens.
  • Usually presents with primary amenorrhea and or infertility.
  • They are phenotypically and psychologically female.
  • Breast development is adequate.
  • There is eunuchoidal tendency (long arms, big hands and feet).
  • Absent or sparse axillary and pubic hair.
  • External genitalia looks female.
  • Vagina is short and blind .The upper two-thirds of vagina, uterus and tubes are absent due to the effect of AMH. The gonads (Sertoli cells) secrete AMH (Anti-Müllerian hormone).
  • Gonads (testes) are either placed in the labia, or inguinal canal or intra-abdominal
  • Investigation:
    • Sex chromatin is negative.
    • Karyotype is 46, XY.
    • Confirmation of diagnosis is by gonadal biopsy -
      • Seminiferous tubules are small, hyalinized.
      • Spermatogenesis is absent.
      • Leydig cells and Sertoli cells are normal.

questions.text: What is the earliest radiographic finding in patients with genitourinary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Moth-eaten calyces are the earliest finding in a patient with genitourinary tuberculosis, seen on intravenous pyelography. It refers to the ragged, feathery calyceal outline due to irregular erosions of the calyx. 

This appearance is due to necrotizing papillitis, which further progresses to form medullary cavities that eventually communicate with the collecting system.

Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus, always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB. It can affect the kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, epididymis, and vas deferens. 

Lesions caused by tuberculosis in the kidney include:

  • Papillary ulcer - earliest lesion.
  • Pyonephrosis - caused by multiple scattered papillary ulcers undergoing caseous necrosis, which later become filled with pus.
  • Perinephric abscess -  by extension of pyonephrosis or tuberculous renal abscess.
  • Pseudocalculi - occurs when calcium gets deposited in a papillary ulcer healed with fibrosis.
  • Ghost calyces - caused by the destruction of the calyces.
  • Putty/cement kidney: Amorphous dystrophic calcification eventually involves the entire kidney (seen in X-ray and CT).

The illustration below shows the lesions caused by tuberculosis in the urinary tract, followed by an IVP depicting moth-eaten calyces. 

The given image shows the signs of renal papillary necrosis.

questions.text: A 9- year-old boy was brought with colicky pain, nausea, vomiting. Lab investigations revealed eosinophilia and stool examination shows the following egg. Which interleukin is secreted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
A child with colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting with eosinophilia likely has a parasitic infection with Ascaris lumbricoides (egg shown in the image). Parasitic infections trigger the release of  IL-5.

In a parasitic infection, Th2 cells are stimulated and they produce IL-4 and IL-5. IL-4 stimulates the differentiation of B-cells into IgE-secreting plasma cells, while IL-5 stimulates the maturation and release of eosinophils from the bone marrow. The secreted IgE coats the parasite. The activated eosinophils bind to the IgE-coated parasite and kill them through the release of major basic protein. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Baseball finger results due to ______
questions.solution:
Baseball finger is also called as Mallet's finger. It results from the sudden flexion of the distal inter phalangeal joint such that the extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint is avulsed from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx.

Depending on whether the thin extensor tendon is torn in its substance or pulls off a small piece of bone at its insertion, two types of injury are recognized:

  • Mallet finger of tendon origin
  • Mallet finger of bony origin

questions.text: Heparin does not cause_____
questions.solution:
• Heparin can inhibit the synthesis of aldosterone by the adrenal glands and occasionally cause hyperkalemia.
  • Long term heparin therapy can result in osteoporosis (option a).
  • Heparin use can be associated with thrombocytopenia; a condition called heparin induced thrombocytopenia (option c).
  • Hepatic function tests abnormalities occur frequently with heparin. Mild elevations of hepatic transminases without elevation in bilirubin/alkaline phosphotase activity is seen (option d).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.solution:
Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema.

Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure (ICP).

"Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate a disc swollen from other causes.

All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass.

Features of papilledema:

  • Raised ICP
  • Edema of the optic nerve head
    • Blockage of axoplasmic flow
    • Axonal swelling
    • Collection of extracellular fluid
  • Painless progressive loss of vision
  • Enlargement of the blind spot
  • Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is at increased risk of breast cancer as she is on hormone replacement therapy. Which of the following is the most sensitive method of screening for this condition?
questions.solution:
Mammography is the most sensitive and specific investigation for detecting breast cancer.

It can detect even small tumors that are missed during a self-breast examination, clinical examination by the physician and ultrasonographic examination.

October is breast cancer awareness month. This is an annual campaign to educate people about breast cancer, the importance of early detection and treatment. In India, breast cancer accounts for 25% to 31% of all cancers in women.

questions.text: The approach shown in the image is a part of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Detect – Treat – Prevent – Build approach for eliminating TB in India is part of the National Strategic Plan for TB (2017-2025). The components of this approach are:

  • Detect - Early identification of presumptive TB cases, at the first point of care, be it private or public sectors, and prompt diagnosis using high sensitivity diagnostic tests.
  • Treat - Provide sustained, equitable access to high quality TB treatment, care and support services.
  • Prevent - Prevent the emergence of TB in susceptible populations.
  • Build - Undertake critical management reforms, restructuring of HR and financial norms, pathways for private sector participation, in order to improve efficiency, effectiveness.

questions.text: What is the approximate weight of the fetus , if the height of the uterus above pubic symphysis is about 35cm and station of head -2?
questions.solution:
Estimation of fetal weight using Johnsons formula:

If station of fetal head is below the ischial spine

  • Fetal weight = (Ht of uterus above pubic symphysis [in cms] – 11) ⨯155

If station of fetal head is at or above ischial spine

  • Fetal weight = (Ht of uterus above pubic symphysis [in cms] – 12) ⨯155

In the given question, the station of head= -2 ,  is Above the ischial spine,

Height of uterus above pubic  symphysis = 35 cm

hence,

Fetal weight = (35-12) ⨯155    = 23⨯155    = 3,565 gm

Approximate weight = 3.5 kg.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of chloroquine resistant malaria in children?
questions.solution:
Clindamycin can be used in children for chloroquine resistant cases . It is safe to use in children and pregnant women.

Chloroquine is not effective in chloroquine resistant malaria (Option A).

Doxycycline and tetracycline are not preferred due to their effect on teeth and bones especially in children < 8years. (option B and C )

Macrolide antibiotic azithromycin is also safe for use in young children and pregnant women.

Clinical Note - Tetracyclines and clindamycin indicated in malaria are slow acting. They are usually combined with fast or intermediate-acting agents.

questions.text: A patient presents to your clinic with the following deformity. In which of the following conditions is this deformity seen?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid arthritis(RA). Swan-neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.


Some of the other small joint deformities of the hand in a patient with RA include:


Boutonnière deformity with flexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the DIP joint. 


Z-line deformity with hyperextension at the DIP joint and subluxation of the 1st metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking and reaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema and tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluating the frontal sinus is Caldwell's view.

It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: In small cell carcinoma all of the hormone levels given will be increased except
questions.solution:
Paraneoplastic syndromes are common in patients with lung cancer, especially those with SCLC, and may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence.

Hormones produced by Small cell lung cancer include:

  • ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone)
  • ANP (Atrial natriuretic peptide or atrial natriuretic factor - ANF)
  • ADH (Antidiuretic hormone  or Arginine vasopressin - AVP)
  • Gonadotropins
  • Calcitonin

Small cell lung cancer:

  • Previously called as Oat cell lung cancer.
  • Usually present with central masses.
  • Associated with cigarette smoking.
  • Causes hypokalemia and hypocalcemia.
  • Highly malignant and metastatic lung cancer.
  • Treatment: Chemotherapy with or without radiotherapy.

questions.text: An old woman presents with a persistent productive cough and clubbing. On auscultation, wheeze and crackles are present. There is no history of fever. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. HRCT is the investigation of choice - most specific.

Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of the bronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases (infections, congenital or autoimmune disorders) that result in the destruction of the bronchial wall and its surrounding supporting tissues. 

Ried’s classification divides bronchiectasis into 3 types based on the phenotype of the affected bronchi:

  • Cylindrical or tubular (most common)
  • Saccular or varicose
  • Cystic

Traction bronchiectasis is a type of bronchiectasis seen in conditions causing extensive pulmonary fibrosis (tuberculosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). The mechanical traction due to fibrosis pulls apart the adjacent bronchi, making them distorted and abnormally dilated. There is no destruction of the bronchial wall.

Clinically, they have a chronic productive cough, clubbing, crackles, and rhonchi.

questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section is shown below. Identify the staining method.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards a diagnosis of syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis. It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Mixing wave of stomach originates in_____
questions.solution:
Mixing waves originate in the body of the stomach.

Mixing waves are the peristaltic movements that macerate food, mix it with secretions of the gastric glands, and reduce it to a soupy liquid called chyme.

Note : Fundal muscle is thought to be electrically quiescent or produce slow waves. The best answer is body of the stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is associated with defective glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI)?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria results from mutation of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)

GPI is necessary for the attachment of decay-accelerating factor (DAF) (CD55) and CD59 to the RBC membrane. Because of the absence of DAF when GPI is mutated, the complement system attacks the RBCs resulting in hemolysis. Patients present with symptoms of: 

  • Anemia
  • Esophageal spasm
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Abdominal pain
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Treatment is with eculizumab, which is a terminal complement inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Diseases due to glycoprotein defect

Diseases Defect Characteristics
I-cell disease Mutation in GNPTA gene leading to a deficiency in enzyme UDP-N-acetylglucoseamine-1-phosphotransferase
  • Coarse facial features
  • Corneal erosion
  • Failure to thrive
  • Hepatomegaly
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency, type II Mutations affecting activity of Golgi-located GDP-fucose transporter 
  • Neutrophil rolling
  • Life-threatening, recurrent bacterial infections
  • Psychomotor and mental retardation
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Genetic mutation leading to the inability to synthesize the glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor that binds certain surface proteins to cell membranes.
  • Lysis of red cells
  • Abdominal pain
  • Back pain
  • Esophageal spasms
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Fatigue
  • Progressive chronic renal failure
  • Thrombophilia
  • Bone marrow failure
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Aplastic anemia
Ehlers–Danlos syndrome Deficiency or mutation in Lysyl hydroxylase-1  
  • Neonatal kyphoscoliosis
  • Generalized joint laxity
  • Skin fragility
  • Severe muscle hypotonia at birth
Oligosaccharidoses Lack of a specific lysosomal hydrolase for glycoproteins
  • Delay in intellectual and physical development.
  • Seizure
  • Joint stiffness and pain
  • Problems with vision and hearing
  • Anaemia, nose bleeds, and easy bleeding or bruising
  • Swollen abdomen due to enlarged spleen or liver. 
Congenital disorders of glycosylation   Glycosylation of a variety of tissue proteins and/or lipids is deficient or defective
  • Fatal, malfunction of several different organ systems
Familial tumoral calcinosis (FTC) UDP-GalNAc transferase 3
  • Calcium deposits in skin and subcutaneous tissues
  • Unresponsiveness to parathyroid hormone
Walker–Warburg syndrome (WWS) Defective α-dystroglycan
  • Agenesis of corpus callosum
  • Anal atresia
  • Atresia of the external auditory canal
  • Blindness
  • Buphthalmos
  • Cerebellar dysplasia
  • Cleft upper lip
Hereditary erythroblastic multinuclearity with positive acidified serum lysis test (HEMPAS) Defects in alpha–mannosidase II
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis
  • Haemolysis & erythroblast morphological abnormalities
  • Hypoglycosylation of some red blood cell (RBC) membrane proteins

questions.text: While performing this block the patient experienced sudden pain in the eye, proptosis, diminished vision, and a sudden increase in intraocular pressure. What procedure-related complication would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of retrobulbar block and the complication that can be suspected in this patient is retrobulbar hemorrhage.

A retrobulbar block is a regional anesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery which involves the injection of a local anesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the outer and middle third of the orbit. After aspiration to rule out intravascular injection, 2 to 5 mL of local anesthetic (lidocaine 2% or bupivacaine 0.75%) is injected, and the needle is removed.

Complications of retrobulbar block include:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication) - Venous hemorrhage spreads slowly but arterial hemorrhage can produce a rapid swelling. This may compress surrounding vital structures and present with marked proptosis, immobility of the globe, inability to close the lids, and blood staining of the conjunctiva and the lids. Compression on the retinal vasculature can cause severe vision loss. 
  • Postretrobulbar block apnea syndrome: This may occur if the anesthetic is injected into the optic nerve sheath.
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Respiratory arrest

Contraindications of retrobulbar block:

  • Bleeding disorders - This is because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage 
  • High myopia - Increased length of the globe increases the risk of perforation
  • Open eye injury (penetrating eye injury) - injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

Other options:

Option A: Retinal detachment: Can present with non-specific symptoms initially, but later present with photopsia (transient flashes of light), floaters (small moving spots in the retinal field), or a gradually developing veil/ curtain obscuring field of vision.

Option B: Subconjunctival haemorrhage: It is usually asymptomatic, but a momentary sharp pain or a snapping sensation can be felt. It is seen on elderly individuals and occurs either spontaneously or follows trauma, surgery or conjunctivitis.

Option C: Optic neuritis: It is characterised by loss of vision, deteriorating in hours to days, along with local tenderness. Often the vision improves spontaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Wilms tumor?

choices.text: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
It is associated with the  deletion of chromosome 11p13
The most common presentation is hematuria

questions.solution:
Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13.

It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominal mass.

Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: Which is the rate-limiting enzyme in beta-oxidation of fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1 (CPT-1), is the rate-limiting enzyme in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

CPT-1 is responsible for transferring the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine which can enter the outer mitochondrial membrane. Thus the acyl group enters the mitochondria from the cytoplasm.

Malonyl CoA is an inhibitor of CPT-I. Thus,

  • In the fed state, with high insulin: glucagon ratio, acetyl CoA carboxylase is active and malonyl CoA is produced, which inhibits β-oxidation.
  • In the fasting state, with low insulin: glucagon ratio, acetyl CoA carboxylase is inactive and malonyl CoA is not produced. Hence, β-oxidation takes place.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.

The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³.

It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen.

  • Total blood count:
    • Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. 
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections.
    • 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells.
  • Peripheral smear:
    • Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
    • Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears.
    • Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.
    • Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both)
  • Lymph node biopsy:
    • Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates
    • Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL.

The chromosomal defects:

  • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
  • Deletion of 11q
  • Trisomy 12q
  • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The image shows Babcock’s forceps.

In Babcock’s forceps, the distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out. The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations. It has a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold tubular structures such as parts of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, etc.

Option A: Allis tissue forceps have distal blades, not opposing each other. The tip has got teeth in each blade that are opposing. There is a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold skin flaps, fascia, aponeurosis, and the bladder wall.

Option C: Lane’s tissue holding forceps have got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestrae. It has an opposing tooth on the tip and a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option D: Kocher’s hemostatic forceps - It is identified by the opposing tooth on the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used to hold ribs during rib dissection, gauze for blunt dissection, and resected bowel.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with complaints of fever, malaise, and weight loss. His lab investigations showed mild anemia, elevated ESR, and serology was positive for cANCA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis) is the most likely diagnosis as it is associated with cANCA.

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about the given distribution of ages of patients attending a geriatric medicine clinic?

Age in years: 70, 70, 76, 76, 80, 83, 84, 85
questions.solution:
For the given dataset, the modes are 70 and 76. The mode is the most frequently occurring value. It can have multiple values. In this scenario, the values 70 and 76 have been repeated twice. 

Median of this distribution is the central value, (76 + 80) / 2 = 78.

Related Pearl: The Mode in Biostatistics

  • The mode is most frequently occurring observed value in a distribution.
  • A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.
  • If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.
  • If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.
  • The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.
  • Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

questions.text: A Gene Xpert test was conducted on the sputum sample of a patient with suspected TB. The results were positive and showed resistance to rifampicin. What is the primary mechanism of resistance against this drug?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin resistance is primarily due to alteration in the target enzyme. 

Rifampicin acts by binding to the β subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (rpoB) and inhibits chain formation in RNA synthesis. Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19. Alteration of the target enzyme (rpoB) by a mutation in the gene coding for rpoB is the primary mechanism of resistance to rifampicin. Gene Xpert identifies mutations in the rpoB gene to detect rifampicin resistance.

Efflux pump induction has also been demonstrated as a mechanism of rifampicin resistance.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient presented with myalgia, difﬁculty in climbing stairs, getting up from squatting position, and combing his hair for 3 months. An edematous purplish-red periorbital rash was seen. Investigations revealed elevated creatinine kinase levels. Muscle biopsy revealed perifascicular and perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates with muscle fiber degeneration. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Dysphagia points to a worse prognosis
20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy
Dilated capillary loops in nail fold can be seen

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of dermatomyositis. Muscle tenderness is not common in this disorder.

It is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle and usually presents initially with a facial rash especially around eyelids which can be pruritic and sore. Myositis symptoms are usually weakness and fatigue especially while climbing stairs, raising arms, and standing from sitting due to proximal muscle weakness.

The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

The clinical signs seen in dermatomyositis are as follows:

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron papules - flat-topped lichenoid eruption on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joint
  • Shawl sign or V sign - fixed erythematous macular erythema)
  • Nail fold changes with periungal erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare
  • Calcinosis cutis

Approximately 20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy (eg, lung, ovarian, breast) and hence screening should be done at the time of diagnosis.

The image below shows ragged cuticle and periungueal erythema in a patient with dermatomyositis.

questions.text: Serum alkaline phosphatase is increased in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Serum alkaline phosphatase is normal in multiple myeloma.

Serum bone-specific alkaline phosphatase is an indicator of osteoblastic activity and is increased in

  • Paget’s disease or osteitis deformans
  • Rickets/osteomalacia
  • Primary or secondary hyperparathyroidism
  • Renal osteodystrophy

It remains normal in

  • Osteoporosis
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Hypoparathyroidism

questions.text: The germ theory of disease stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. Who advanced this theory?
questions.solution:
Louis Pasteur advanced the germ theory of disease, which stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms.

He is also known for the following contributions:

  • Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation.
  • Developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera.
  • Pioneer of techniques of pasteurization and sterilization.

Scientist/ Doctor

Achievements 

Susruta

Father of Indian Surgery

Father of Plastic and Cosmetic Surgery

Author of “Susruta Samhita” 

Hippocrates

First True Epidemiologist

Father of Medicine

Author of “Airs, Water and Place” 

Charaka

Father of Indian Medicine

Author of “Charaka Samhita” 

Avicenna

Author of “Canon of Medicine” and “The Book on Healing”

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with jaundice and abdominal pain. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium. MRCP reveals multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: Todani classification is used for this condition
This condition is also known as Caroli's disease
Central dot sign is a characteristic CT finding associated with this condition
Endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Caroli's disease (type V choledochal cyst). Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice here.

Choledochal cysts are cystic dilations of the common bile duct (CBD). They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

There are mainly five types of choledochal cysts. The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, has been modified by Todani.

MRCP is the investigation of choice. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and central dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. 

The arrows in the image given below are pointing to the central dot sign.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A woman with pathological myopia visits the ophthalmology OPD for an annual eye check-up. What is the least likely finding to be seen on her ophthalmologic examination?
questions.solution:
The shallow anterior chamber is not a feature of pathological myopia.

Signs of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Prominent eyeballs
  • Large cornea
  • Deep anterior chamber (AC)
  • Fundus picture
    • Large, pale optic disc with the temporal myopic crescent
    • Degenerative changes in retina and choroid
    • Foster Fuchs spots (blackish spots due to retinal pigment epithelial hyperplasia)
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy
  • Posterior staphyloma
  • Degenerative changes in the vitreous—posterior vitreous detachment

questions.text: False about CURB-65 criteria to assess pneumonia severity is
questions.solution:
CURB-65 includes systolic blood pressure ≤ 90 mmHg as criteria, not ≤ 100 mmHg.

The CURB-65 is used to assess the severity of pneumonia.

It includes five variables:

  • Confusion
  • Urea >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥65 years

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important risk factor for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome occurs primarily in premature infants. Its incidence is inversely related to gestational age and birthweight. It occurs in 60–80% of infants delivered at <28 wk of gestational age, in 15–30% of those delivered between 32 and 36 weeks of gestational age, and rarely in those delivered at >37 wk of gestational age.

Other risk factors include the following:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Multiple births
  • Cesarean delivery
  • Asphyxia
  • History of previously affected siblings

questions.text: The image given below depicts an x-ray of the knee in a term baby. Which among the following conditions is associated with it?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the X-ray image is the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, which is a typical radiological feature of congenital hypothyroidism.

X-ray findings in hypothyroidism

  • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses at birth.
  • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis (multiple foci of ossification)
  • Deformity or beaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebra
  • X-ray image of the skull shows large fontanels and wide sutures; wormian (intrasutural) bones; and, often, an enlarged and round sella turcica.

Image below: The infant on the left with congenital hypothyroidism demonstrates the absence of the distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses, while in the normal infant on the right the distal femoral epiphysis is present:

 

The image below shows small upper femoral epiphyses:

 

The image below shows enlarged sella turcica and wormian bones (intrasutural):

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shows looser zones, codfish vertebrae, and champagne glass pelvis in radiographic images?
questions.solution:
Looser zones, codfish vertebrae, and champagne glass pelvis are seen in osteomalacia.

Loosers zones are the classical lesions of osteomalacia. These are due to incomplete stress fractures caused by the arterial pulsations which heal with callus-lacking in calcium. They are thin transverse bands of rarefaction especially seen in the pelvis, the shaft of long bones such as femur neck and the axillary edge of the scapula. They are seen in:

  • Osteomalacia (characteristic)
  • Renal osteodystrophy
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Paget's disease 
  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta 

The image below shows Looser's zone.

Codfish vertebrae are the biconcave vertebral bodies seen in osteomalacia. They are seen in:

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Osteomalacia
  • Osteoporosis

The image below shows the codfish vertebrae.

Champagne glass pelvis is due to bone softening leading to lateral indentation of acetabula. It is seen in:

  • Osteomalacia
  • Achondroplasia

questions.text: Which of the following physiologic processes is not correctly matched?

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-B receptors decrease K+ conductance.
Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-A receptors increase Cl– conductance.

questions.solution:
GABA-B receptors are present in the spinal cord and appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. 

PRE-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION

  • Presynaptic inhibition is a process mediated by neurons whose terminals are on excitatory endings, forming axoaxonal synapses.
  • The first transmitter shown to produce presynaptic inhibition was GABA. On the pre-synaptic membrane
    • Acting via GABA-A receptors, GABA increases Cl– conductance. 
    • GABA-B receptors appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. 
  • This leads to hyperpolarization of the pre-synaptic membrane and inhibition of release of the neurotransmittor from the pre-synaptic neuron.
 

POST-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION

  • Postsynaptic inhibition occurs when an inhibitory transmitter such as glycine or GABA is released from a presynaptic nerve terminal onto the postsynaptic neuron to induce an IPSP in the postsynaptic neuron.
  • In the figure shown below, an inhibitory transmitter such as GABA is released from the nerve terminals of an inhibitory interneuron (dark) that synapses on a postsynaptic neuron.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of this patient based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows deep S-waves in V6 and large R-waves in V1. This is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).

Diagnostic criteria for RVH:

  • Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1).
  • Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1).
  • Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4) and inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more.

For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria are commonly used.

It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm).

questions.text: Multipurpose health worker scheme in India was introduced by which committee’s recommendation?
questions.solution:
Kartar Singh Committee was also called The Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning.

Related Pearl: Health Planning Committees of India

Year

Name

Concepts and Programmes

1946

Bhore committee
  • Also called Health Survey and Development Committee
  • 1 PHC for 40,000 population
  • 3 million plan
  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels 

1962

Mudaliar committee
  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee
  • District hospitals to have specialists
  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people
  • Constitution of All India Health Service

1963

Chadah committee
  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population 

1965

Mukerji committee
  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

1966

Mukerji committee
  • Also called committee of Health Secretaries.
  • Detailed the Basic Health Service to be given at block level 

1967

Jungalwalla committee
  • Also called Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Ban of private practice by government doctors
  • Equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work

1973

Kartar Singh committee
  • Also called Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning
  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

1975

Shrivastav committee
  • Also called Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower
  • Referral Services Complex
  • Rural Health Infrastructure of Sub centre, PHC and CHC
  • ROME scheme – Reorientation of health education
  • Establishment of Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Village Health Guide scheme
  • Bands of semi–professional and Para-professional Health workers 

1983

Krishnan committee

 
  • Urban Revamping Scheme
  • Integration of PHC       

1986

Bajaj committee
  • Formulation of National Medical and Health Education Policy.
  • Formulation of National Manpower Policy.
  • Health Manpower cells
  • Education commission.

questions.text: Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS) includes which of the following components?
questions.solution:
TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) includes :

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of injury (blunt/penetrating).

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with gross hematuria 2 days after an episode of diarrhoea. The serum C3 levels are normal. Light microscopy demonstrates focal and segmental mesangial proliferation and increased mesangial matrix in the glomerulus. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gross hematuria following a gastrointestinal infection, associated with normal C3 levels, in a male patient is suggestive of immunoglobulin A nephropathy (Berger nephropathy).

  • IgA nephropathy is the most common chronic glomerular disease in children.
  • Focal and segmental mesangial proliferation and increased mesangial matrix are seen in the glomerulus.
  • It is characterized by a predominance of IgA within mesangial glomerular deposits in the absence of systemic disease.
  • It is seen more often in males.
  • Gross hematuria occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection (in contrast to the long latency period observed in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).
  • It can be associated with loin pain.
  • Normal serum levels of C3 in IgA nephropathy (help to distinguish this disorder from PSGN).
  • Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic value because they are elevated in only a few paediatric patients.

questions.text: The novel prostaglandin agonist called latanoprostene bunod is to be used for which of the following purposes?
questions.solution:
• Latanoprostene bunod (LBN) is an ophthalmic solution which is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.
  • It is an NO-donating prostaglandin F2 alpha receptor agonist.
  • It reduces the intraocular pressure by increasing aqueous outflow through the trabecular meshwork and uveoscleral routes.
  • Common side-effects include conjunctival hyperemia, eye irritation and pain in the instillation site.
  • It is administered as eye drops to be instilled once a day in the evening.
  • If other drugs are being used for the eye, it has to be given 5 minutes apart.
  • It was approved for this usage by the FDA in 2017.

questions.text: All of the following are the features of Pulmonary Alveolar proteinosis, except _______
questions.solution:
LDH level is elevated in PAP.

Pulmonary Alveolar proteinosis:

  • PAP is an autoimmune disease with a neutralizing antibody of immunoglobulin G isotype against granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF).
  • Thus neutralization of GM-CSF bioactivity by the antibody causes dysfunction of alveolar macrophages, which results in reduced surfactant clearance.

Pathogenesis: Impaired ability to clear surfactant.

3 different classes of PAP are seen:

  • Acquired (MC).
  • Congenital- Auto-somal recessive transmission with frame shift mutation of SP-B gene.
  • Secondary- Rare in adults.

Caused by:

  • Lysinuric protein intolerance.
  • Acute silicosis.
  • Inhalational syndromes.
  • Immunodeficiency syndromes.
  • Hematopoietic malignancies.

Features:

  • Progressive exertional dyspnoea.
  • Fatigue.
  • Weight loss.
  • Low grade fever.
  • Non productive cough.

Lab findings:

  • Polycythemia.
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia.
  • Increased LDH.
  • Elevated serum levels of Lung surfactant proteins A and D.
  • Elevated Anti GM-CSF titre is seen in serum and BAL fluid.

Radiological findings:

  • Chest X-ray: B/L symmetric alveolar opacities in middle and lower lung zones- Bat wing distribution.
  • HRCT: Ground glass opacification and thickened intra lobular structures.

Special features:

  • PAS positive amorphous lipo-proteinaceous accumulation in distal air spaces.
  • Preservation of underlying architecture of lung.

Treatment :

Whole lung lavage through a double lumen endotracheal tube.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a serine protease?
questions.solution:
Chymotrypsinogen is a zymogen. Its active form chymotrypsin is a serine protease.

Serine proteases are proteolytic enzymes having serine, histidine and aspartate at the active site. Active site consists of two binding sites and a catalytic site. While serine is present in the catalytic site of serine proteases, histidine and aspartate are present on binding sites. Serine proteases differ in substrate specificity.

Examples of serine proteases :

  • Chymotrypsin
  • Trypsin
  • Elastase
  • Thrombin
  • Plasmin
  • Complements
  • Factor X and XI
  • Prostate-specific antigen.

Related Pearl: Enzyme classification

There are seven groups of enzymes according to IUBMB.

E.C. NO. Enzyme class Type of reaction catalyzed with examples
1 Oxidoreductases

Catalyze redox reactions

  • Dehydrogenase
  • Oxygenase
  • Oxidase
  • Catalase
  • Peroxidase
2 Transferases

Catalyze the transfer of functional groups from one substrate to another.

  • Kinases
  • Transaminases
  • Transmethylases
3 Hydrolases

Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.

  • Lipase
  • Arginase
  • Pepsin
  • Esterase
4 Lyases

Catalyze the cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, thereby generating double bonds.

  • Aldolase
  • Fumarase
  • HMG-CoA lyase
  • Arginosuccinase
5 Isomerases

Catalyze structural changes within a molecule.

  • Phosphohexoisomerase
  • Mutase
  • Racemase
6 Ligases

Catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions.

  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • PRPP synthetase
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase
  • Glutamine synthetase
7 Translocases Catalyze the movement of molecules or ions across membranes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman after a trivial fall presents with pelvic fracture along with left femoral nerve injury. The function of all of the following muscles will be affected except:
questions.solution:
Gracilis is supplied by the obturator nerve and not the femoral nerve. Hence, the function of gracilis muscle will be normal in this patient.

Branches of the femoral nerve:

  • Before entering the thigh, the femoral nerve supplies branches to the iliacus and pectineus muscles
  • The anterior division of femoral nerves supplies the sartorius and gives sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the thigh by the branches medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh and intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • The posterior division of the femoral nerve supplies branches to the quadriceps femoris muscles, knee joint and gives sensation to the medial aspect of the leg by the saphenous nerve.

The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.

questions.text: The best circuit for controlled ventilation is:
questions.solution:
Mapleson circuit type D is the circuit of choice for controlled ventilation and it is the most commonly used circuit. This can also be used for spontaneous ventilation.

In Mapleson circuits or semi-closed circuits, the exhaled gases from the patient are partly exhaled from the atmosphere and partly used by the patient.

Mapleson Circuit type   Comments  
Type A (Magill circuit)  Circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation 
Type B  It is a semi-closed circuit 
Type C (Water's to and fro)  It is a coaxial system (fresh gas tube and exhaled gases are in same axis) 
Type D (Bain circuit)  Circuit of choice for controlled ventilation. Most commonly used circuit .Can also be used for spontaneous ventilation 
Type E (Ayre's T piece)  Circuit of 2nd choice in children 
Type F (Jackson-Rees circuit)  Circuit of choice in children

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The attachment of which ​of the following fascia prevents extravasation into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Colle's fascia prevents the extravasation of the urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle. 

Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the superficial fascia of the scrotum and becomes the Colles' fascia. In women, it continues into the labia majora and is continuous with the fascia of the perineum. Colle's fascia has the following attachments:

  • Posterior - perineal membrane. It prevents the extravasation of fluids such as blood, pus, or urine into the anal triangle. 
  • Lateral - ischiopubic rami and fascia lata along Holden's line. This line extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. It prevents the extravasation of fluids into the thigh. 

Option A: Camper's fascia is the superficial fatty layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option B: Scarpa's fascia is the deep membranous layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option C: Buck's fascia is the deep fascia of the penis 

Clinical significance:

When a urethral injury occurs, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, scrotum, labia majora and the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is rushed to the emergency department because of an episode of fits associated with uprolling of eyes and high fever. Kernig’s sign is negative and there are no post-ictal neurological deficits. There is a history of a similar episode when the child had a fever due to gastroenteritis. Which of the following is false regarding this type of seizures?

choices.text: Likelihood of developing epilepsy is low
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions
Absence of having a developmental delay

questions.solution:
This is a probable case of febrile seizures due to the presence of high fever, no post-ictal deficits and a negative Kernig's sign ruling out meningitis. Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure, as the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly.

Febrile seizures are seizures that-

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails or in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.solution:
Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adult dose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children.

Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used in trachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in a large-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide application of azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy. 

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: Werner classification is used for?
questions.solution:
Werner classification is done for assessing severity of ophthalmopathy in graves disease.

Werner classification:

  • Werner classification reflects the severity of the ophthalmopathy.
  • It is well known by the acronym of NO SPECS.
  • Each grade is further subdivided as 0-4 and a-c.

Grades of Werner classification:

Grade  Feature  Acronym 
0  No signs or symptoms  N 
1  Only signs (lid retraction)  O 
2  Soft tissue involvement (chemosis, grit)  S 
3  Proptosis (minimum <23, moderate, marked >28)  P 
4  Extraocular muscle involvement  E 
5  Corneal involvement  C 
6  Loss of Sight  S

questions.text: A patient who presented to the OPD with a papulosquamous lesion has the following nail finding. Histopathology of the skin lesion is unlikely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image showing nail pitting and salmon patches in fingernails are characteristic of psoriasis. Munro microabscess is seen in psoriasis whereas Pautrier's microabscess is seen in mycosis fungoides.

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides)

The image below shows histopathology of psoriasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding salivary gland tumors?

choices.text: 90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant
The submandibular gland is the most common site for salivary tumors
Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland
A salivary gland tumor with perineural invasion is mucoepidermoid carcinoma

questions.solution:
90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, and the common sites are the upper lip, palate, and retromolar regions.

Option B: The most common site for salivary tumors is the parotid gland, mostly involving the superficial lobe.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known to be associated with perineural invasion.

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.
