questions.text: An elderly male patient presents with kyphosis and bowing of legs. There is increased warmth over his limbs and he is diagnosed with high frequency sensorineural hearing loss. His X-ray skull is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing cotton wool skull and Tam O'Shanter appearance is suggestive of Paget's disease.

The rapid bone formation and resorption in Paget's disease can lead to increased blood flow within the bone and the surrounding tissues. This leads to increased warmth over the limbs. They may also have kyphosis and bowing of legs. Increased bone formation in Paget's disease may lead to the narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This causes compression of the cranial nerves which may lead to deafness.

Deafness due to the narrowing of cranial nerve foramina is also seen in osteopetrosis. However, it can be differentiated from Paget's disease by the absence of lytic lesions of the bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding alpha helix?

choices.text: Stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from the peptide bond.
A complete turn of an alpha helix contains 3.6 amino acyl residues.
Pitch of the helix is 0.54 nm.
Large numbers of charged amino acids disrupt the helix.

questions.solution:
Alpha helix is stabilized primarily by intra-chain hydrogen bonds. 

Alpha helix is the most common and stable secondary structure of protein. It is a rigid, right-handed spiral. A complete turn of the helix contains an average of 3.6 aminoacyl residues. The rise per turn of the helix (pitch) is 0.54nm. 

Large numbers of charged amino acids (glutamate, aspartate, histidine, lysine, and arginine) disrupt the helix by forming ionic bonds or by electrostatically repelling each other.

questions.text: Arrange the following stages of a family cycle in chronological order:

choices.text: Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution, Contraction, Complete contraction
Formation, Extension, Contraction, Complete extension, Complete contraction, Dissolution
Formation, Contraction, Complete contraction, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution
Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution

questions.solution:
Family cycle has 6 phases in the order of:

Phases of family lifecycle  Beginning of phase End of phase
Formation Marriage Birth of the 1st child
Extenssion Birth of the 1st child Birth of last child
Complete extension Birth of last child 1st child leaves home
Contraction 1st child leaves home Last child leaves home
Completed contraction Last child leaves home 1st spouse dies
Dissolution 1st spouse dies Death of survivuor

questions.text: With reference to hyaline cartilage, the isogenous cell groups are formed by ______
questions.solution:
The isogenous cell groups in hyaline cartilage, are formed by chondrocytes.

  • Hyaline (glass-like) cartilage is a bluish, opalescent, homogenous cartilage.
  • The cartilage is surrounded by perichondrium. Just beneath the perichondrium, the chondrocytes are flat, which become larger and rounder as they enter the deeper tissue.
  • The characteristic feature of the hyaline cartilage is the presence of two or more chondrocytes that are arranged in groups. These groups of cells are formed by division of a single cell, and hence, they are known as isogenous cell group of cell-nests.
  • The chondrocytes are present within the cavities of the matrix, called lacunae.
  • The matrix surrounding the individual or group of chondrocytes is deeply stained and is called territorial matrix or lacunar capsule.
  • Whereas, the rest of the matrix is pale stained, and is called interstitial or interterritorial matrix.

questions.text: The urinary bladder shown in the MCU image below is diagnostic of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder, in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall. It is typically seen in severe neurogenic bladder.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.

There are five types of neurogenic bladder based on the site of the lesion.

  1. Sensory neurogenic bladder: Posterior columns of the spinal cord or afferent tracts leading from the bladder
  2. Motor paralytic bladder: Damage to motor neurons of the bladder
  3. Uninhibited neurogenic bladder: Incomplete spinal cord lesions above s2 or cerebral cortex or cerebropontine axis lesions
  4. Reflex neurogenic bladder: Complete spinal cord lesions above s2 - may lead to pine cone bladder
  5. Autonomous neurogenic bladder: Conus or cauda equina lesions

 

Note:

Occasionally, Christmas tree bladder is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage during the disaster?
questions.solution:
• In triage, green is low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.
  • Red is a high priority or transfer; yellow is medium priority and black is dead or moribund patients.
  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • It is done at the site of the disaster.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: ​​You are preparing to administer the BCG vaccine to a newborn at a PHC. Before administering the vaccine, you check the vaccine vial monitor. In which of the following observations on the VVM, will you discard the vaccine?

choices.text: Inner square has the same color as the outer circle
Inner circle has the same color as the outer square
Inner circle is lighter than the outer square

questions.solution:
A vaccine must be discarded if the VVM shows the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Lupus Pernio is diagnostic of chronic form of?
questions.solution:
• Skin involvement is eventually identified in over a third of patients with sarcoidosis.
  • The classic cutaneous lesions include erythema nodosum, maculopapular lesions, hyper- and hypopigmentation, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules.
  • A specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks is referred to as lupus pernio and is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: In micturition reflex, the first change to occur is_____
questions.solution:
• One of the initial events is the relaxation of the muscles of the pelvic floor, and this may cause a sufficient downward tug on the detrusor muscle to initiate its contrac­tion.
  • Micturition Reflex
  • Micturition is fundamentally a spinal reflex facili­tated and inhibited by higher brain centers and is subject to voluntary facilitation and inhibition.
  • These centers include
    • strong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pons
    • several centers located in the cerebral cortex that is mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory.
  • The micturition reflex is the basic cause of micturition, but the higher centers normally exert final control of micturition.
  • Micturition Reflex is the result of a stretch reflex initiated by sensory stretch receptors in the bladder wall, especially by the receptors in the posterior urethra when this area begins to fill with urine at the higher bladder pressures.
  • Sensory signals from the bladder stretch receptors are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then reflexively back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers by way of these same nerves. (refer figure)
  • As the bladder continues to fill, the micturition reflexes become more frequent and cause greater contractions of the detrusor muscle.
  • Once a micturition reflex begins, it is “self-regenerative.”
  • It is a single complete cycle of
    • The progressive and rapid increase of pressure,
    • A period of sustained pressure, and
    • Return of the pressure to the basal tone of the bladder.
  • As the bladder becomes more and more filled, micturition reflexes occur more and more often and more and more powerfully.
  • Once the micturition reflex becomes powerful enough, it causes another reflex, which passes through the pudendal nerves to the external sphincter to inhibit it. If this inhibition is more potent in the brain than the voluntary constrictor signals to the external sphincter, urination will occur. If not, urination will not occur until the bladder fills still further and the micturition reflex becomes more powerful.

questions.text: The main cytokine, involved in erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) reaction is:
questions.solution:
• Elevated levels of circulating tumor necrosis factor (TNF) have been demonstrated in ENL. Thus, TNF may play a central role in the pathobiology of this syndrome.
  • Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is a type 2 lepra reaction which occurs exclusively in patients near the lepromatous end of the leprosy spectrum (BL/LL).
  • The most common features of ENL are crops of painful erythematous papules that resolve spontaneously in a few days to a week but may recur.
  • However, patients may also experience symptoms of neuritis, lymphadenitis, uveitis, orchitis, and glomerulonephritis and may develop anemia, leukocytosis, and abnormal liver function tests.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was brought to the casualty with confusion and gait instability. Medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, requiring multiple hospitalizations in the past. On examination, he appears inattentive, has bilateral horizontal nystagmus, and his gait is slow and wide-based. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a medical emergency. Thiamine administration (100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks) may reduce the risk of it progressing to chronic Korsakoff psychosis which is irreversible. 

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Thiamine is a cofactor (TPP) in glucose metabolism. Thus, starting dextrose infusions before thiamine administration will exacerbate the existing thiamine deficiency, precipitating Wernicke’s disease. Thiamine is also involved in the conduction of the axon potential and synaptic transmission. 

Alcohol abuse leads to thiamine deficiency by the following mechanisms:

  • Poor nutritional habits
  • Folate deficiency - reduces thiamine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Direct damage of the intestinal mucosa

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder characterized by the clinical triad (GOA):

  1. Global Confusion
  2. Ophthalmoplegia ( first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  3. Ataxia

questions.text: Vegetations on the undersurface of cusps are found in ________
questions.solution:
In Libman–Sacks endocarditis, vegetations are found on either or both sides of the valve leaflets.

questions.text: Imaging of a patient with recurrent epistaxis shows the following finding. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: Tumor does not have a capsule
Digital palpation should never be done in OPD

questions.solution:
The image shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, which is called an antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. It is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Recurrence of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is common. 

It is a rare tumor but is the commonest benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. It does not have a capsule. 

Digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, as it can lead to severe hemorrhage.

questions.text: Under the ESI Act, which of the following is not given as a cash benefit?
questions.solution:
Under the ESI Act, medical benefit is not given as a cash benefit. It is provided in the form of consultations, investigations and treatment by means of the ESI hospitals or ESI dispensaries.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Identify the skin condition shown in this photograph of a newborn.
questions.solution:
The neonate is most likely suffering from Harlequin ichthyosis, as evidenced by the presence of armor-like skin.

It is the most devastating type of autosomal recessive congenital icthyosis. It is due to mutations of the ABCA12 gene. The gene plays a role in lamellar body formation in the stratum granulosum and desquamation of the stratum corneum. 

It presents in the neonatal period with armor‐like skin (truncal plates with fissuring). It can impair body movement and breathing. Bilateral ectropion and eclabium are present. Respiratory problems are the major cause of death due to alveolar collapse in neonates. They are also prone to skin and lung infections.

Defective lamellar bodies in the stratum granulosum seen in electron microscopy are pathognomic of Harlequin ichthyosis. In early life, constant supportive care is required. Treatment includes moisturizing cream, antibiotics, etretinate, or retinoids.

Other options - 

Option A) Ichthyosis vulgaris - The most common type of ichthyosis, involving mutations in filaggrin protein. Filaggrin is an epidermal protein that helps retain moisture in the stratum corneum. Ichthyosis is not present at birth but develops during the first months of life. The scaling usually involves the extensor surfaces of the extremities with flexural sparing. They are strongly correlated with atopic dermatitis and other forms of atopy such as allergic rhinitis, asthma, etc.

Option B) Bathing suit ichthyosis is a type of congenital ichthyosis caused by mutations in the TGM1 gene. It presents as a collodion baby at birth where the neonate is encased in a shiny parchment‐like membrane. Shedding of the collodion membrane is followed by the development of large dark grey/brownish scales affecting the trunk and the scalp, but sparing the face and extremities resembling a bathing suit. The disease tends to become worse in the summer months and improves in winter.

Option D) Lamellar ichthyosis is also a congenital ichthyosis, involving mutations in the TGM1 gene. It is characterized by large plate‐like dark‐brown hyperkeratoses covering the entire body with mild palmoplantar involvement. The extreme spectrum of lamellar ichthyosis is congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE) which is similar to erythroderma seen in psoriasis.

questions.text: Who was the first person to synthesize nitrous oxide?
questions.solution:
Joseph Priestley first synthesized nitrous oxide in 1772. 

Joseph Priestley, an English chemist is well known for his experiments and observations on different kinds of air. He is most famously known for the discovery of "dephlogisticated air," which was later named oxygen by Lavoisier.

Humphry Davy, in 1800, first noted the analgesic properties of nitrous oxide. 

Horace Wells studied the analgesic properties of nitrous oxide and put into clinical use in 1844 for dental extraction but it was less potent than ether.

William Morton introduced ether anesthesia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with an abdominal mass. On examination, the mass is firm, smooth, non-tender, and does not cross the mid-line. The boy is also found to have moderate hypertension. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria. Wilms tumor is suspected. This condition can be associated with all of the following except  ___________.
questions.solution:
Polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilm's tumor.

Wilms tumor (WT), also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. 

Polycystic kidney disease can also present with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. However, there will be multiple irregular cysts on ultrasound and is not associated with Wilms tumor.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: A man presented with progressively worsening cough with sputum, breathlessness, easy fatiguability, and loss of appetite for 6 months. PFT was suggestive of a restrictive disorder.  Trans-bronchial biopsy showed cells positive for CD1a and langerin (CD207). Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?

choices.text: They may present with spontaneous pneumothorax
Cysts and nodules are seen on HRCT
It is a smoking related interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). It is a smoking-related ILD that typically affects young adults. Smoking cessation leads to improvement in the condition.

The specific immunohistochemical markers for LCH are CD1a and langerin (CD207). On electron microscopy, the presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic (as shown below).

HRCT shows bilateral irregularly shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe. There is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax in this condition due to cyst rupture.

questions.text: In which stage of sleep are K complex and sleep spindles seen?
questions.solution:
Stage 2 of NREM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (12–14 Hz) and occasional high-voltage biphasic waves called K complexes.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: Immunofluorescence microscopy of a skin biopsy from a patient shows IgA deposits as shown. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Patients present with papules and vesicles over extensor areas
Lymphocytic microabscesses are seen in dermis

questions.solution:
Granular deposits of IgA on direct immunofluorescence are suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis or Duhring's disease. The characteristic microscopic feature is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils.

It presents as grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, scalp which are associated with intense pruritus.

questions.text: While monitoring the respiratory rate of the infants in the NICU, you notice one baby which suddenly stops breathing. Which of the following statements is true in this regard?

choices.text: Primary apnea is characterized by  labile BP and tachycardia
Caffeine therapy should be given in primary apnea
Secondary apnea responds to stimulation by establishing normal breathing.
Central asphyxia can cause secondary apnea

questions.solution:
Secondary apnea can occur as a central CNS meditated asphyxia or due to neuromuscular disorders. 

Apnea is the cessation of breathing for >20 seconds or for any duration if accompanied by bradycardia and cyanosis. 

Primary Apnea  Secondary Apnea
Failure to initiate respiratory effort at birth Apnea developing in an infant who has initiated a respiratory effort
There may be bradycardia and decreased tone. BP remains normal

Can originate in CNS due to asphyxia or peripherally due to neuromuscular disorders
Respond to tactile stimulation Require ventilatory assistance and drugs- caffeine or theophylline

questions.text: 1 and ½ year old child with history of chronic diarrhea was brought to the hospital with complaints of perioral and perineal rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

  • Autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to defect in intestinal zinc specific transporter – Human ZIP4 protein
  • Genetic locus – Chromosome 8q24.3
  • Classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk.
  • C/F – Perioral and perineal rashes, periungal dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, alopecia.
  • Labs – Low serum zinc, ALP
  • Paneth cell inclusion in intestinal mucosal biopsy
  • Treatment – Zinc – 50mg/ day for infants, upto 150mg/day for children

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the culture of Trypanosoma?
questions.solution:
NNN (Novy, McNeal, and Nicolle) medium is used for the culture of Trypanosoma brucie and cruzie. It is also used for the culture of Leishmania.

The other media used in the culture of Trypanosoma are Weinman's medium and Tobie's medium.

Other options:

Options B, C & D: Boeck and Drbohlav medium, Craig’s medium and NIH polygenic medium are used for the culture of E.histolytica.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cutaneous malignant tumour?
questions.solution:
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer.

  • Amongst the non-melanoma cancers group, Basal Cell Carcinoma constitutes 74%, whereas SCC constitutes 23% only.
  • Melanoma constitutes only 4% of skin cancers but causes 80% of skin cancer-related deaths.

BCC is the most common human cancer. BCCs are malignancies of the skin. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation exposure, human papillomavirus infection, immunosuppression, photosensitizing drugs, occupational factors, arsenic exposure, etc. 

On histopathological examination, BCCs resemble the basal epidermal layer. They can be the multifocal superficial type that extends over the skin surface or the nodular type that grows into the dermis as cords and islands of basophilic cells. They have hyperchromatic nuclei in a mucinous matrix and are surrounded by fibroblasts and lymphocytes. They demonstrate peripheral palisading

The image below shows the histological features of BCC. 

Gross morphology: There are multiple variants of BCC. The most common type is nodular BCC. They are pearly, with a rolled border, and maybe ulcerated. Ulcerated BCCs are called rodent ulcers. Nodular BCCs are most commonly present on the head and neck. 

The below image shows a nodular BCC with ulceration over the supraorbital area

BCCs are generally diagnosed clinically. If there is doubt, then a shave or punch biopsy can be performed depending on the subtype of BCCs.

Treatment involves both removing the lesion and maintaining cosmetic appearance. BCCs can be managed medically with imiquimod, 5 fluorouracil, and intralesional interferon alpha-2b. Surgical methods involve excision with predetermined margins, curettage and cautery, and Moh's micrographic surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an autosomal dominant condition?
questions.solution:
Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive inherited disorder of copper metabolism that is characterized by excessive deposition of copper in the liver, brain, and other tissues.

In Wilson disease, the processes of incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin and excretion of excess copper into bile are impaired. The transport of copper by the copper-transporting P-type ATPase is defective due to one of several mutations in the ATP7B gene.

(Rose) Rickets
(College) Chronic granulomatous disease
(All) Alport syndrome (common inheritance pattern)
(Girls) G-6-PD deficiency
(Children) Type X Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease
(Don’t) Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Diabetes insipidus
 
(Care) Color blindness
 
(About) Agammaglobulinemia, Alport syndrome, Ocular albinism
 
(Foolish) Fabry disease
  
(Words) Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  
Other conditions: Menke's disease, Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency

questions.text: You can use 'A' scan for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Assessment of vitreous hemorrhage is done by "B" scan.

Both 'A' and 'B' scans are types of ultrasound (USG) scans.

A scan (time amplitude) B scan (intensity modulation)
It produces a unidimensional image and echoes are plotted as spikes. It produces a two-dimensional dotted section of the eyeball.

Uses:

  • Axial length
  • Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation: Biometry
  • Anterior chamber depth
  • The thickness of intraocular mass

Uses:

  • Assessment of the posterior segment in opaque media
  • Study of intraocular tumors
  • Localization of intraocular and intra-orbital foreign bodies

 

The first image below shows "A" scan ultrasound amplitude spikes.

The second image shows a normal "B" scan of the eye.

questions.text: Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called
questions.solution:
• Object permanence is a major developmental milestone, attained at the age of 8-9 months. It is the understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen.
  • Object permanence is firmly established by 18 months of age; toddlers anticipate where an object will end up, even though the object was not visible while it was being moved.

 Other options:

  • Separation anxiety – the child becomes clingy and cries anxiously at bedtime or when separated from the parents. Separation anxiety begins about 10 mo of age and tapers off by 18 mo.
  • Transitional object – it may be a blanket or a stuffed toy which functions as a symbol of the absent parent.
  • Egocentric symbolic play seen at 12 months - Make-believe (symbolic) play centers on the child’s own body (pretending to drink from an empty cup) ; Symbolic transformations in play are no longer tied to the toddler’s own body by 18 months, so that a doll can be “fed” from an empty plate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor involving the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor, while pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.

Histological classification and incidence of tumors of salivary glands:

Benign Tumors Incidence Malignant tumors Incidence
Pleomorphic adenoma 50% Mucoepidermoid carcinoma 15%
Warthin’s tumor 5–10% Adenocarcinoma (NOS) 10%
Oncocytoma 1% Acinic cell carcinoma 5%
Other adenomas 5–10% Adenoid cystic carcinoma 5%
Basal cell adenoma  1-2% Malignant mixed tumor 3–5%
Canalicular adenoma 1%  Squamous cell carcinoma 1%
Ductal papillomas  - Other carcinomas 2%

NOS: Not otherwise specified.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which is the most abundant gonococcal surface protein?
questions.solution:
Porin is the most abundant gonococcal surface protein.

Based on the class of Porin there are two main serotypes:

  • porB.1A - associated with disseminated gonococcal infection.
  • PorB.1B – associated with local genital infections.

The outer membrane porin molecule of Neisseria gonorrhoeae is known as protein I (PI).Among different strains of gonococci there is variability of PI, and two main classes, PIA and PIB, have been recognized.

questions.text: A farmer was diagnosed with brucellosis. Which of the following patterns of fever will be seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. 

Other options

Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days.

Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria.

Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue.  Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C  with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.

questions.text: Suicidal tendency is associated with decreased levels of ______
questions.solution:
Suicidal thoughts are associated with decreased levels of serotonin and 5HIAA in plasma and urine respectively.

Neurotransmitters in mood disorders

  • Depression: Decreased serotonin, norepinephrine and dopamine
  • Mania: Increased levels of norepinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would you not expect to see in a patient with Wolfram syndrome?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus is a clinical component of Wolfram syndrome, and not SIADH. 

Characteristics of Wolfram syndrome include:

  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Optic atrophy
  • Sensorineural deafness

(Mnemonic DIDMOAD)

Wolfram syndrome is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

questions.text: You are asked to conduct an autopsy of a person who was found dead at his home. You notice the given findings on the body. Which test can be used to differentiate this from antemortem bruising?
questions.solution:
The given image shows postmortem hypostasis. The classic test used to differentiate a bruise from hypostasis is the incision test. 

The suspected area is incised to see if the underlying blood is intravascular (hypostasis) or infiltrating the tissues outside the vessels (contusion).

Option A: Gettler's chloride test is used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. It is not widely used now. 

Option C: In the precipitin test, a specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid, blood, or saliva. A positive test will confirm human origin.

Option D: Breslau's second life test is done to determine whether a child was born alive or not.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
• The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with respect to the change in intrapleural pressure, which is compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Applied aspect:

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: You are the second-year ENT resident performing tonsillectomy in a patient with chronic tonsillitis. While creating a dissection plane between the capsule and the bed of the tonsil, you accidentally deepened the incision, injuring the tonsillar bed. Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is not related to the bed of the tonsil and is the least likely structure to be injured in this scenario.

The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

The lower fossa is related to:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve
  • The styloid process

Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to:

  • The facial artery
  • Submandibular salivary gland
  • Posterior belly of the digastric muscle
  • Medial pterygoid muscle
  • The angle of the mandible

questions.text: Wastewater without human excreta is called_______
questions.solution:
Sullage or greywater is all wastewater generated in domestic areas without fecal contamination.

Blackwater is wastewater from domestic areas that has fecal contamination.

Sewage, also called domestic or municipal wastewater is a type of wastewater produced by a community in total. It contains both blackwater and greywater (sullage).

Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of primary treatment of sewage.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hematuria and melena for 10 days. Laboratory investigations reveal mild thrombocytopenia and normal coagulation tests. Peripheral smear is given below. Which organism is most frequently involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide.

This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk.

The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells seen in HUS.  

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS

questions.text: X-ray tube in mammography differs from that of a normal X-ray machine in that it has _______.
questions.solution:
Conventional X ray tube has :

  • Glass window
  • Aluminium filter

Mammography has

  • Beryllium window
  • Molybdenum filter

questions.text: Lipid peroxides can be estimated by _______

choices.text: Ferrous oxidation in xylenol orange assay
Ferric oxidation in xylenol orange assay

questions.solution:
Lipid peroxides can be measured by the ferrous oxidation in xylenol orange (FOX) assay.

The total body radical burden can be estimated by measuring the products of lipid peroxidation.

  • FOX assay: Under acidic conditions, they oxidize Fe2+ to Fe3+, which forms a chromophore with xylenol orange.
  • The dialdehydes formed from lipid peroxides can be measured by reaction with thiobarbituric acid, when they form a red fluorescent adduct—the results of this assay are generally reported as total thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, TBARS.
  • Peroxidation of n-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids leads to the formation of pentane, and of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids to ethane, both of which can be measured in exhaled air.

questions.text: Which of the following pathological changes occurs in the small vessels of patients suffering from hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hypertension results in hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the small vessels.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel walls, leading to:

  • Dissection
  • Aneurysm formation
  • Cerebrovascular hemorrhage
  • Acceleration of atherosclerosis

questions.text: According to the Glasgow Outcome Score, what score will you give to a patient who is in a persistent vegetative state following a head injury?
questions.solution:
A persistent vegetative state is given a score of 2, according to the Glasgow Outcome Score.

The Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) is different from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), and it is used to quantify the degree of recovery achieved after a head injury, especially for research purposes.

The scoring system is as follows:

Patient condition Score
Good recovery 5
Moderate disability 4
Severe disability 3
Persistent vegetative state 2
Dead 1

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding autism?

choices.text: Language impairment is a usual feature
It is never associated with intellectual disability
Symptoms present in the early developmental period
Patients may show an inflexible adherence to routines

questions.solution:
Intellectual disability is seen in about 30% of patients with autism.

Autism or autistic diorder is a pervasive developmental disorder. Features usually start before 3 years of age and is more common in boys. Autism is characterized by the 2 core features of autism spectrum disorder: deficits in social communication and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

In addition, autism is also usually marked by language impairment, which occurs early in the developmental period. However this is not a core feature.

Below-normal intelligence is seen in about 30% of children with autistic disorder. However, some autistic children have unusual abilities in some areas (e.g., exceptional memory or calculation skills). These are referred to as savant skills.

World Autism Awareness Day is observed annually on April 2nd, to embrace the concept of neurodiversity — the idea that people experience and interact with the world in many different ways and that there is no one “right” way. This year's theme is “Transformation: Toward a Neuro-Inclusive World for All”

Related Pearl: Autism Spectrum Disorder

 

  Autism Rett syndrome Asperger syndrome Heller syndrome
Onset Before 3 years After 5 months After 3 years After 2 years
Gender predilection Boys Girls Boys Boys
Intellectual disability Present in 30% of the cases Present Absent Present
Language Mostly poor Mostly poor Normal Mostly poor
Remarks ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

 ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

NOTE: Rett's syndrome has been removed from DSM-5 because it was found to have a clear genetic basis.

 
DSM - 4
DSM - 5
Change in Classification 
Pervasive Developmental disorders
Autistic Spectrum Disorder
Number of Domains 
3 domains
2 domains
Impairment in social interaction and communication 
 

  • Delay or total lack of development of spoken language

  • Stereotyped and repetitive use of language

  • Impairment in the use of multiple nonverbal behaviors

  • Failure to develop peer relationships

  • Lack of social or emotional reciprocity
 
 

  • Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors

  • Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships

  • Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity 
Repetitive and restricted
interests/behaviors 
 
  • Stereotyped and repetitive motor mannerisms

  • Inflexible adherence to specific, nonfunctional routines

  • Persistent preoccupation with parts of an object
 

  • Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements

  • Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines

  • Highly restricted, fixated interests.

  • Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given sign seen?
questions.solution:
The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestack appearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition.

Amsler grid is used for: 

  • Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy.
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked 'A' in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The area marked 'A' is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung.

The diagram shown is of the right lung, identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text:
Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in the order of frequency of occurrence.
  1. Pouch of Douglas
  2. Uterosacral ligament
  3. Broad ligament
  4. Ovary
  5. Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
The sites of endometriosis arranged in the order of frequency of occurrence are: Ovary > Pouch of Douglas > Broad ligament > Uterosacral ligament > Fallopian tube.

Endometriotic lesions have been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Which of the following hearing defects is not seen in otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Presbyacusis is not seen in otosclerosis.

The following hearing defects are seen in otosclerosis:

  • Painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss most commonly.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss may be seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis.
  • Paracusis willisii: Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard.

questions.text: A middle-aged-man presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. Which of the following features rules out Meniere’s disease and is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
Rollover phenomenon is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. It is a feature of retro-cochlear/neural lesions wherein the speech discrimination steadily increases with intensity but suddenly drops significantly beyond a particular intensity of sound.

Meniere’s disease is an important differential for acoustic neuroma as the patients suffer from similar symptoms. Meniere’s is a cochlear pathology and acoustic neuroma is retrocochlear.

Option A - Stapedial reflex is present in cochlear lesions (Meniere’s) and absent in retrocochlear lesion (acoustic neuroma)

Option B - Recruitment phenomenon is the abnormal growth in loudness in the affected ear, seen in cochlear pathologies. 

Option C - SISI (short increment sensitivity score) is a test of intensity discrimination which is very high in cochlear pathologies but low in retro-cochlear.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen did not ferment lactose or mannitol. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
questions.solution:
Shigella dysenteriae does not ferment mannitol and lactose.

Shigella species cause bacillary dysentery (bloody diarrhea with abdominal cramps). They do not ferment lactose, except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter. To differentiate between the various Shigella species, mannitol fermentation is noted. 

Classification of pathogenic Shigella species:

Designation Group Mannitol Fermentation Ornithine decarboxylase

Lactose Fermentation
S. dysenteriae A - - -
S. flexneri B + - -
S. boydii C + - -
S. sonnei D + + Late lactose fermenter

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy develops discolouration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Black dermographism is characterized by discoloration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object.

Dermographism refers to an exaggerated flare and weal response that occurs when skin is stroked or scratched. Dermographism is the most common form of chronic inducible urticaria or physical urticaria.

Other options:

  • White dermographism: This is due to capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking of the skin and occurs normally but is particularly pronounced in atopic eczema
  • Symptomatic dermographism: The triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin accompanied by severe itching.
  • Urticaria pigmentosa: Presence of itchy pigmented macules on the trunk of a child due to numerous deposition of cutaneous mast cells.

questions.text: A young man presented with complaints of a tingling sensation in his hands and feet. He also complains of weakness in his legs that is slowly spreading to his upper body. He had an episode of bloody diarrhea 10 days ago.  Which of the following organisms is the likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with ascending paralysis is suggestive of the development Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) following diarrhea. The organism that likely caused this patients condition is Campylobacter jejuni, which can cause diarrhea and trigger GBS. 

Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. Growth occurs under microaerophilic conditions. The organism also shows darting motility. Asymptomatic campylobacter infection also may trigger Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. In C. jejuni infection, bacterial lipopolysaccharide triggers an autoimmune response against axons via molecular mimicry, hence causing GBS. Other organisms associated with GBS include cytomegalovirus, M. pneumonia, and Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: “Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in which phase of a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
“Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in phase II of a clinical trial.

Phase II of clinical trials

  • It involves a small group of patients (50-500).
  • Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.
  • The study is designed to obtain "Proof of concept"(Potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

 

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: A young lady who is on oral contraceptive pills refrains from taking any drug even for minor ailments due to the fear of contraceptive failure. Which of the following drugs can be taken safely?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, aspirin use is least likely to cause contraceptive failure.

Option B: Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracycline suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen. This leads to lowering of plasma estrogen levels and can result in contraceptive failure.

Options C and D: Enzyme inducers like phenytoin and rifampicin increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives and can cause contraceptive failure.

questions.text: For which of the following post-translational modifications is vitamin K needed?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K is needed for carboxylation. 

The principal role of vitamin K is in the post-translational modification i.e, γ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in proteins such as :

  • Coagulation factors : Factor II, VII, IX, X
  • Protein C and S
  • Osteocalcin
  • Nephrocalcin

In the process of γ-carboxylation, the vitamin K hydroquinone is oxidized to vitamin K epoxide by epoxidase.

  • Vitamin K epoxide is reduced to the quinone form by epoxide reductase, which is sensitive to inhibition by warfarin.
  • The quinone form is reduced to the active hydroquinone form by quinone reductase.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with hyperuricemia and delayed developmental milestones. He also has the habit of biting his lips, fingers, and feet because of which he is always strapped to the bed. Urine examined showed orange sands. Which is the most probable enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is caused due to the complete deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine, from which excessive amounts of uric acid is produced and excreted in urine as orange sands.

Clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, hyperuricemia, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements and megaloblastic anemia.

Diagnosis is made by deficient HGPRTase enzyme activity in the erythrocyte. Partial deficiency of HGPRTase cause Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase enzyme deficiency causes urinary calculus formation with crystalluria.

Option C: Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the  2nd major cause of SCID.

Option D: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase causes a severe deficiency of T cells but B cells are normal.

questions.text: Which of the following works by disrupting the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Lysol works by disrupting the cell membrane. 

Lysol is a phenol compound, which is obtained by distillation of coal tar. Phenols cause cell membrane damage and inactivate membrane-bound oxidases and dehydrogenases. This causes lysis and release of cell contents. Low concentrations of phenol can precipitate proteins. They are not inactivated by organic matter and are thus useful disinfectants. 

The mechnisms of action of other disinfecting agents are:

  1. DNA damage
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Ultraviolet light
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • DNA reactive chemicals like acriflavin. 
  2. Protein modification
    • Alcohol
    • Chlorine
    • Iodine
    • Heavy metals (e.g. thiomersal)
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
    • Ethylene oxide
    • Acids and alkalis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Pradhan mantri poshan shakti nirman?

choices.text: It is a centrally sponsored scheme aimed at addressing hunger and education
Cooked meal is provided only to preschool children
Objective is to make children attend school regularly
It is provided in government and government aided schools

questions.solution:
Pradhan mantri poshan shakti nirman (PM POSHAN) is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides cooked meals for preschool children and children up to standard VIII

The main objective is to improve hunger and education by 

  • providing hot-cooked meals in government and government-aided schools.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding CRISPR-Cas9?

choices.text: It is a system used by bacterial cells to recognise and destroy viral DNA as a form of adaptive immunity
It is a tool which is designed to detect TB
It is tool designed to test air pollution
It is a tool used in DNA sequencing

questions.solution:
The CRISPR-Cas9 system, found in many bacteria, represents a form of acquired, or adaptive immunity to infection by bacteriophages, which complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases.

In recent years, a novel DNA editing/gene regulatory system termed Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats- CRISPR-associated gene 9 (CRISPR-Cas9) has been developed. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

Within bacteria, this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

questions.text: A man brings his wife to the psychiatric OPD, reporting concerns about her recent behaviour. She complains of irritability, distractibility, and reduced need for sleep. Her husband observes that she has an elated mood, talks excessively, and struggles to manage her daily activities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of decreased sleep, elation, talkativeness, irritability, and distractibility present for at least 1 week is characteristic of mania.

Diagnostic criteria for mania:

A. Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting at least 1 week or any duration if hospital­ization is necessary.

B. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy/activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms and four (or more) if irritable have been present to a significant degree:

  1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
  2. Decreased need for sleep
  3. More talkative than usual
  4. Flight of ideas
  5. Distractibility
  6. Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
  7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences

C. The episode is severe enough to cause marked social or occupational impairment or to necessitate hospitalization.

D. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or to another medical condition.

Related Pearl: Mania Vs Hypomania

Mania Hypomania
Symptoms for at least 1 week Symptoms for at least 4 days
Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning No impairment in social or occupational functioning
May need hospitalization Doesn't need hospitalization

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Pap smear in 40 year old females
Screening of immigrants in a country
Screening for urine sugar in 40 year old males

questions.solution:
Prospective screening is done for control of a disease and usually for the benefit of others like screening immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis and syphilis.

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection and people are screened for their own benefit like neonatal screening and Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

Testing for urine sugar in men over 40 would also be prescriptive screening.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought to the casualty in a confused state. On examination, he has severe muscle rigidity. His son says that the patient is on treatment for Parkinson's disease but has forgotten to take his medication as they went on a holiday trip. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Abrupt withdrawal of levodopa or dopaminergic agonists can precipitate neuroleptic malignant syndrome. It is characterized by extreme rigidity, confusion, and hyperthermia. 

It is an emergency condition that can turn fatal if immediate intervention is not done. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is commonly associated with the use of typical antipsychotics.

Option A: Wearing off phenomenon - Each dose of levodopa improves mobility for a period of 1-2 hours. After that, the effect of the drug wears off, and rigidity and akinesia return. This can be surpassed by increasing the dosing and frequency.

Option B: On/off phenomenon - Rapid fluctuation between on and off periods.

  • On period: When the patient has a beneficial effect of the medications but with disabling dyskinesias
  • Off period: No beneficial effects from anti-Parkinsonism medications.

'Wearing off' and 'On / Off' phenomenon occur with long-term treatment of levodopa.

Option D: Serotonin syndrome occurs with co-prescription of MAO-inhibitors and SSRIs.

questions.text: Which of the following is an antimetabolite?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analog that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in denovo purine and thymidylate synthesis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium.

Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected.

Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text: A woman, weighing 58 kg, has second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area.  Which of the following formulae would you use to calculate the amount of fluid to be given?

choices.text: Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 2 = volume in mL
Percentage of burns × weight (kg)/2 =  volume in mL
Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 4 = volume in mL
Weight + 1500 ml/m2×BSA burnt = volume in mL

questions.solution:
According to the latest ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) 10th edition 2018, resuscitation formula for second and third-degree thermal burns in the first 24 hours is given by the following equation:

Total percentage body surface area burned × weight (kg) × 2 = volume (mL).

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours. This has been recommended to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. 

Adequacy of fluid resuscitation is assessed by monitoring for a urine output of 0.5-1.0 mL/kg/hr.

However, in cases of electrical burns, the formula is: 

Total percentage body surface area burned× weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL).

Parkland and Modified Parkland formula:

  • Parkland's formula for resuscitation in the initial 24 hours is given by =  Total percentage body surface area × weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL).
  • Modified Parkland's formula provides more specific recommendations for the second 24 hours, advising colloid infusion of 5% albumin at the amount of 0.3-1.0/mL/kg/%BSA/hr. The management of the first 24 hours remains the same.

NOTE : Resuscitation formulas are not used in cases of superficial burns and in non-superficial burns with <20% TBSA

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: Examination of a resected specimen of an ovarian mass reveals signet ring cells are seen as shown below. Which of the following conditions is this associated with?
questions.solution:
Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor.

A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy that metastasized from a primary site, most commonly from the stomach (70%). Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites.

The route of spread may be:

  • Lymphatic
  • Hematogenous
  • Transcoelomic

They are usually bilateral and have a smooth surface with a waxy consistency. They retain the shape of a normal ovary.

Given below are the images of the Krukenberg tumor's gross appearance and histological appearance with signet ring cells:

questions.text: The three-stage classification of burns was provided by:
questions.solution:
The three-stage classification of burn degrees was provided by Wilson.

Wilson classification of burns:

  • First degree - Erythema and blistering without loss of dermis
  • Second degree - Destruction of the full thickness of skin
  • Third-degree - Destruction of deeper tissues below the skin

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations involving non-coding regions?
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease is due to CAG (trinucleotide) repeat mutation in the coding region of the gene, not the non-coding region. 

Expansion of trinucleotide repeats is an important genetic cause of human disease, particularly neurodegenerative disorders. The causative mutations are associated with the expansion of a stretch of trinucleotides that usually share the nucleotides G and C. In all cases, the DNA is unstable, and an expansion of the repeats above a certain threshold impairs gene function.

Expansions affecting noncoding regions will cause a loss of function mutation. They include:

  • Fragile X syndrome
  • Myotonic dystrophy
  • Friedreich ataxia

Expansions affecting coding regions cause a gain of function mutation. They include:

  • Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease)
  • Huntington disease
  • Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (Haw–River syndrome)
  • Spinocerebellar ataxia types 1, 2, 3, 6, 7

questions.text: Identify the organization that has the given emblem:

choices.text: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme
National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke

questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP).

Characteristics of NLEP emblem:

  • The lotus in the NLEP emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb, a normal forefinger, and the shape of a house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of leprosy.

NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Option A: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

Option C: Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS)

Option D: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of mortality in patients with organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution: The most common cause of death in organophosphate poisoning is respiratory failure. It usually occurs within 24 hours in untreated patients, secondary to paralysis of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect of parathormone?
questions.solution:
PTH does not increase phosphate reabsorption in kidney, rather it causes decreased phosphate reabsorption in the kidney.
