questions.text: Not a part of “Triple therapy” immunosuppression for post-renal transplant patient is
questions.solution:
Belatacept is not part of “Triple therapy” immunosuppression for post-renal transplant patient.

  • The most frequently used combination is triple therapy with
    • Prednisone
    • Calcineurin inhibitor (Tacrolimus - 1st line or Cyclosporine)
    • Antimetabolite (Mycophenolate mofetil or Azathioprine)
  • Mammalian TOR (mTOR) inhibitors can replace one of the last two agents.

Note: More recently, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved a new co-stimulatory blocking antibody (CD80 & CD86), belatacept, as a new strategy to prevent long-term calcineurin inhibitor toxicity. It is indicated for prophylaxis of organ rejection in patients who are EBV seropositive and receiving a kidney transplant.

questions.text: Hounsfield units is used in CT density scale to measure attenuation value of different materials compared to water. The value of fat in HU would be around
questions.solution:
The value of fat is around -100 HU.

In a CT density scale

  • Air = -1000 (Black)
  • Fat = -100
  • Water = 0
  • Concealed blood = +60 to +70
  • Calcification = +1000 (White)

questions.text: Massive myoclonus is a hallmark of which stage of SSPE?
questions.solution:
Clinical stages of subacute sclerosis panencephalitis:

Stage  Clinical manifestations 
Stage I  Personality changes, failure in school, strange behaviour  
Stage II  Massive, repetitive, and frequent myoclonic jerks, seizures and dementia  
Stage III  Rigidity, extrapyramidal symptoms, and progressive unresponsiveness  
Stage IV  Coma, vegetative state, autonomic failure, and akinetic mutism

questions.text: A police inspector is investigating a murder case. The victim was brutally beaten and raped. The body had noose marks on the neck which seemed to be the cause of death. However, during the investigation, the inspector never showed any emotion. What defense mechanism is described here?
questions.solution:
The defense mechanism described is isolation. It is the separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

It is usually developed in an attempt to avoid painful thoughts or feelings by emotionally detaching oneself from the feeling.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: All of the following can be a differential diagnosis of the condition shown in the below CT scan except
questions.solution:
The above CT scan shows miliary mottling which is not seen in Diffuse pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

Causes of miliary mottling are:

  • Miliary TB
  • Loeffler pneumonia
  • Bronchopneumonia
  • Interstitital lung disease
  • Hemosiderosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Histiocytosis – X

Diffuse pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis:

  • Seen in Premenopausal women
  • HRCT – Multiple thin walled cysts surrounded by normal lung.
  • C/F include:
    • Emphysema
    • Recurrent pneumothorax
    • Chylous pleural effusion

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes macrovesicular steatosis of liver?
questions.solution:
Macrovesicular fatty liver (steatosis) is seen in obesity.

Macrovesicular steatosis is characterized by a single, large vacuole of fat that fills up the hepatocyte and displaces the nucleus to the periphery. Causes include:

  • Late alcoholic liver disease
  • Obesity
  • Protein-energy malnutrition
  • Non-alcohlic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Chronic hepatitis C

Microvesicular steatosis is characterized by small intracytoplasmic fat vacuoles, which accumulate in the cell. Causes include:

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
  • Reye syndrome
  • Early alcoholic liver disease
  • Drugs and toxins 

The image given below shows macrovesicular and microvesicular steatosis of liver:

questions.text: All of the following findings would satisfy the Amsel criteria except:
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs are not included in Amsel’s criteria. Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the alteration of normal vaginal flora. It is not an inflammation. Hence, only a few polymorphs are seen on saline microscopy.

Amsel’s criteria are used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  1. A homogenous vaginal discharge
  2. A vaginal pH of > 4.5
  3. An amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test)
  4. Presence of clue cells

If three out of the above-mentioned four criteria are positive, then a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is made.

questions.text: You are researching the overall burden of COVID on a given population. Which of the following disability indicators is the best measure of this?
questions.solution:
Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population. It is also the best measure of the effectiveness of interventions. 

DALY is calculated as - Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost to disability (YLD). It can measure both mortality and disability together. 

As DALY is affected by premature loss of life, conditions that affect younger individuals like road traffic accidents have a high DALY. In comparison to this, Alzheimer's disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age and so has a lower YLL.

Related Pearl: QALY vs. DALY

QALY and DALY are disability indicators used as measures of health in a population.

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years)

 

Measures quality of life in health gain

 

Measures health loss in quality of life

 

Indicator of cost-effectiveness of intervention

 

Indicator of overall burden of disease in a population

 

Expressed as 1 or 0 where,

1 = Perfect health

0 = Death

 

 

Expressed as 0 or 1 where,

0 = Perfect health

1 = Death

questions.text: A 53-year-old man who is a chronic smoker is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. Histopathology of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathology showing the Azzopardi effect are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man came to the casualty 12 hours after sustaining a laceration on his leg from a trekking accident. On closer examination, other than dirt, you do not notice any pus or signs of infection. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Closure after granulation tissue has formed
Delayed closure 2 days after removal of devitalised tissue
Primary closure after adequate wound toileting and debridement
Wound debridement, topical antibiotics and dressing

questions.solution:
Contaminated wounds older than 6 hours should be managed with delayed primary closure. 

The wound is cleaned, debrided, and left open for a few days. This allows soft tissues to drain and also ensures no infection is present before surgical closure can be done. 

Wound closure is categorized into primary, secondary, or tertiary:

Primary closure is done for clean wounds with minimal tissue loss that are amenable to approximation of wound edges. Healing occurs by primary intention. Primary closure is ideally performed within 6 to 8 hrs of trauma, but wounds in vascular areas (e.g. face) may be delayed to up to 24 hours after trauma. 

Secondary closure allows healing by secondary intention. The wound is left open to heal largely by the formation of granulation tissue and contraction. These wounds often have significant tissue loss precluding tension-free approximation of edges, with devitalized edges. Wound dressings are changed daily to aid in the formation of granulation tissue and subsequent contraction. 

Tertiary closure, also known as delayed primary closure, results in a combination of healing by primary and secondary intention. The wound is thoroughly irrigated, debrided, and left open for 2 to 5 days before surgical closure. It is used for wounds that are grossly contaminated without significant tissue loss.

questions.text: In which of the following patients can thiopentone be administered safely?

choices.text: A 24-year-old woman with history of acute intermittent porphyria
A 52-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

questions.solution:
Thiopentone can be safely administered in a patient with raised intracranial tension, i.e., brain tumor.

Thiopentone is cerebroprotective as it reduces CSF volume by facilitating its absorption. It also decreases cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume and helps in lowering intracranial pressure.

The other options are contraindications to the use of thiopentone.

Option B: Thiopentone induces aminolevulinic acid synthetase, which increases the formation of porphyrins. This precipitate porphyria attacks, especially acute intermittent porphyria or variegate porphyria in susceptible individuals.

Option C: Thiopentone should be avoided in hypovolemic or shock patients because of the significant reduction in cardiac output (69%) and arterial blood pressure due to vasodilation and venous pooling.

Option D: Thiopentone produces dose-related central respiratory depression, producing a characteristic ventilatory pattern called 'double apnea'.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset fever with chills and malaise. On examination splenomegaly was present. Bone marrow picture is shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the bone marrow picture showing macrophages infected with intracellular Leishman-Donovan bodies point towards a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis. Hydroxychloroquine is not indicated in the treatment of this condition.

The drugs effective in visceral leishmaniasis are: 

  • Liposomal amphotericin B (preferred)
  • Sodium stibogluconate (not in India)
  • Miltefosine
  • Paromomycin
  • Pentamidine (rarely used)

Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial agent and is also used in the treatment of dermatological conditions like: 

  • Cutaneous lupus erythematosus
  • Cutaneous dermatomyositis
  • Polymorphous light eruption
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nuclei are present in both the general somatic efferent and general visceral efferent column?
questions.solution:
Oculomotor nerve nuclei are present in both general somatic efferent (GSE) and general visceral efferent (GVE) columns in the brainstem.

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

Functional Component Cranial nerves 

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

 3,4,6,12

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

 3,7,9,10

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

 2,8

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibers, have the GVE component.

questions.text: Which of the following joints are usually spared in osteoarthritis?
questions.solution:
The elbow is usually spared in osteoarthritis.

Osteoarthritis of the knee is most common.

Commonly affected joints in osteoarthritis include cervical and lumbosacral spine, hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal joint.

In the hands, proximal and distal interphalangeal joints and the base of the thumb are affected. 

Note: Our joints were designed (in an evolutionary sense) for apes, animals that still walked on four limbs. We thus tend to develop OA in joints that were ill designed for human tasks such as pincer grip (OA in the thumb base) and walking upright (OA in knees and hips).

questions.text: A known diabetic with an HbA1c value of 9% should be classified under which ASA-PS classification?
questions.solution:
A patient with poorly controlled diabetes should be classified as ASA-PS Class III.   

ASA-PS Class III: A patient with severe systemic disease and substantial functional limitation. Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus or hypertension or complicated diabetes is included under ASA-PS Class III. 

Note: If the question was about well-controlled diabetes or mild diabetes without complications, the answer would be ASA-PS Class II.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A patient is referred for the evaluation of severe right-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal X-ray appears normal, and a USG revealed the presence of a 6mm renal stone. Which of the following stones is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone.

Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated with disorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopic examination, the crystals appear as glass shards.

Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol.

Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

Radiolucent Renal Stones

Mnemonic: X UTI

  • Xanthine
  • Uric Acid (most common)

Drug induced renal stones

  • Triamterene
  • Indinavir

questions.text:
In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease?
  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive 1000 50
Test negative 500 3450
Total 1500 3500
questions.solution:
Prevalence is given by the formula: 

In this scenario, the number of cases: 1000+500 = 1500.

Total population: 5000

Prevalence= 1500/5000 × 100 = 30%.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A physician is suspecting dermatomyositis in a 27-year-old woman with complaints of proximal myalgia and dysphagia. The presence of which of the following signs would be pathognomonic of this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of Gottron's papules is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. They are erythematous to violaceous papules that occur symmetrically over the extensor aspects of metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.

Gottron's sign, on the other hand, is erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 

V sign is confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest.

Shawl sign is the confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms.

All these signs are present in dermatomyositis, but Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash are pathognomonic.

questions.text: What signals are carried by the parvocellular pathway from the lateral geniculate body to the visual cortex?

choices.text: Colour vision, shape, and fine details

questions.solution:
The parvocellular pathway gives signals for color vision, texture, shape, and fine details. 

Feature Parvocellular Pathway Magnocellular Pathway
Arises  layers 3, 4, 5, and 6 of LGB  Layers 1 and 2 of LGB
Terminates Layer 4 of visual cortex Layer 4 of visual cortex
Use  Color vision, texture, shape, and fine details Movement, depth, flicker, and spatial organization

LGB: lateral geniculate body

The interlaminar pathway gives signals for color vision to layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex having clusters of cells called blobs.

Related Pearl: Order of neurons in the visual pathway

questions.text: True statement regarding Iodine 131 is all except
questions.solution:
• I-131 emits beta and gamma rays ( and not alpha rays)
  • It is contraindicated in pregnancy
  • It is used in radio-ablation of thyroid.

questions.text: What type of antagonism is shown by drugs A and B in the following dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
The parallel rightward shift of the agonist dose-response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism.

Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

In non-competitive antagonism, there will be flattening of the agonist DRC.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line indicates an enzymatic reaction taking place in the presence of a competitive inhibitor.

The graph represents the enzymatic reaction velocity in relation to substrate concentration. The black line indicates the reaction taking place in the absence of any inhibitor.

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the red line,

  • Vmax remains unchanged.
  • Km  is increased.

In the presence of a non-competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the blue line,

  • Vmax is decreased
  • Km remains unchanged

Note:

Suicide inhibitors are specialized substrate analogs. They contain a chemical group that can be transformed by the target enzyme. After binding to the active site of the enzyme, catalysis by the enzyme generates a highly reactive group that forms a covalent bond and blocks the function of the enzyme.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a ​pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
The maxilla is a pneumatic bone. 

Pneumatic bones contain air-filled cavities, which make them light-weight. They also aid in the resonance of sound and act as air conditioning chambers for inspired air. e.g., maxilla, sphenoid, ethmoid, etc. 

Short bones: Carpal bones and tarsal bones

Flat bones: Sternum, ribs, scapula, and bones of the skull vault

Irregular bones: Hip bones, vertebra, and bones in the base of the skull.

questions.text: An elderly woman was brought to the hospital with a history of severe loin pain for the past 7 hours. Ultrasound of the kidney reveals a 2.5 cm renal stone. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size >2cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). 

In PCNL, endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique, and stones are removed. PCNL is also indicated in:

  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stones >1 cm

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include hemorrhage, perforation of the collecting system, and of the colon or pleural cavity.

Another approach for the management of renal stones is ureteroscopic removal(URS) or retrograde intra-renal surgery (RIRS). In URS, stones are removed via a retrograde approach using a dormia basket, or a Holmium YAG laser is used to break the stones. 

If PCNL or URS fails, open or laparoscopic pyelolithotomy or nephrolithotomy is done.

The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

questions.text: Medlar bodies are found in ______
questions.solution:
Chromoblastomycosis is the most common form of chromomycosis, which is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi.

The MC fungi responsible are species of the genera Fonsecaea (Fonsecaea pedrosoi or Fonsecaea compacta).

Histologically on potassium hydroxide preparation, the lesions show the presence of the fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast like bodies with septae called Sclerotic bodies/medlar bodies/Copper penny bodies. These structures multiply by septation, and they induce a purulent and granulomatous inflammatory reaction in tissue.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. 

Risk factors for developing AF include:

  • Age- usually above 60 years of age
  • Underlying heart disease
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Sleep apnea
  • Post-cardiac surgery
  • Inflammatory pericarditis

Acute precipitating factors for AF include:

  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Acute alcohol intoxication
  • Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

questions.text: The hunter's canal lies beneath which muscle?
questions.solution:
The hunter’s canal lies beneath the sartorius muscle. It is also referred to as the subsartorial canal or adductor canal.

The hunter’s canal is a triangular intermuscular tunnel occupying the lower two-thirds of the medial aspect of the thigh.

Related Pearl: Adductor Canal

           Boundaries of Adductor Canal
Antero-lateral wall Vastus medialis

Adductor magnus (below)

Subsartorial nerve plexus
Contents

questions.text: On examination of a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia, you find his spleen has enlarged towards the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevents its displacement towards the left iliac fossa?

choices.text: Upper pole of the left kidney

questions.solution:
The downward displacement of the spleen towards the left iliac fossa is prevented due to the presence of the phrenicocolic ligament. So the spleen usually enlarges towards the right iliac fossa.

The phrenicocolic ligament connects the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It is not attached to the spleen. However, it lies below the spleen and supports its lower pole. When the spleen gets enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament along with the splenic flexure of the colon restricts its downward displacement.

The phrenicocolic ligament functions as a potential barrier to the spread of infection between the left paracolic gutter and the left subphrenic space.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presented to the hospital after a road traffic accident with a fracture of the pelvis. There was urinary retention and blood at the urethral meatus. On digital rectal examination, he had a high-riding prostate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with blood at the tip of the meatus and high-riding prostate on examination is suggestive of rupture of the membranous urethra.

Rupture Membranous urethra Bulbar urethra
Cause Fracture of the pelvis Blow to the perineum (fall-astride injury-straddle injury)
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at urethral meatus
  • Perineal bruising and hematoma
Investigation Retrograde urethrogram  Retrograde urethrogram

In both cases, the initial management should be the insertion of a suprapubic catheter. Passing a catheter blindly per urethra is not advised as this can convert a partial tear into a complete tear. 

However, delayed urethroplasty is the definitive management for complete urethral tear.

questions.text: A patient presented with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Which of the following types of fibroid is usually associated with this symptom?
questions.solution:
Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle.

Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule out endometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases.

Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increased vascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity.

Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia. For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of a secondary hydrocele ?
questions.solution:
A secondary hydrocele is most commonly caused by an acute or chronic epididymo-orchitis. Other causes of secondary hydrocele include torsion of the testis and testicular tumors.

Primary vaginal hydrocele Secondary vaginal hydrocele
Due to defective absorption of fluid Due to increased secretion of fluid
Tense swelling Lax swelling
Testis not palpable separately Testis palpable separately
Transillumination positive (clear fluid present) Transillumination negative (turbid fluid present)

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic difference between a typical cervical and thoracic vertebra?

choices.text: Cervical vertebrae have longer spinous processes
Thoracic vertebrae  foramina are bigger than the body
Thoracic vertebrae have turbercles on transverse processes

questions.solution:
The typical cervical vertebrae are characterized by a foramen in the transverse process called the foramen transversarium. 

This foramen transversarium transmits the vertebral artery and vein, along with a branch from the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve). Lateral parts of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae also contain the anterior and posterior tubercles.

Feature Typical cervical vertebrae Typical thoracic vertebrae
Vertebral body Smaller and thinner

Intermediate in size between cervical and lumbar

Costal facets for the ribs seen on either the vertebral body, the transverse process, or both
Vertebral foramina Larger and wider than the vertebral body Smaller than the size of the vertebral body
Transverse processes Small and have transverse foramen, and 2 tubercles Longer, larger, and stronger; no transverse foramina 
Spinous processes Horizontally behind the body and usually bifid (C1-C5) Longer and slender; terminates in a distinct tubercle

 The images given below illustrate a typical cervical and thoracic vertebrae respectively.

The anterior tubercle of the 6th cervical vertebra is the longest and is known as the carotid tubercle of Chassaignac. The carotid artery can be compressed against the groove formed by the anterior tubercles and the vertebral bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following secretory immunoglobulin is dimeric joined by a J chain?
questions.solution:
Secretory IgA is a dimer, formed by two monomer units joined  together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide known as J-chain.

  • IgA occurs in two forms – Serum IgA and Secretory IgA
  • Serum IgA is a monomer.
  • Secretory IgA is synthesised by plasma cells situated near the mucosal or glandular epithelium. The J chain is also produced by plasma cells.
  • IgA has an important role in providing mucosal immunity.

IgM is a pentamer, consisiting of 5 subunits, which are joined by J-chain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation.

Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion ≥5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible.

Hysterectomy types include:

  • Type I - Simple / extrafascial
  • Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim
  • Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim
  • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
  • Type V - Exenteration.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: What is the threshold potential of SA node?
questions.solution:
The threshold potential of SA node is -40 to -30 mV.

  • The main role of a sinoatrial node cell is to initiate action potentials, so that it can pass throughout the heart and cause contraction.
  • An action potential is a change in voltage (membrane potential) across the membrane of the cell, produced by the movement of charged atoms (ions).
  • Pacemaker cells, however, don’t have a resting membrane potential unlike non-pacemaker cells. Instead, there is a pacemaker potential where immediately after one action potential, the membrane potential of these cells begins to depolarise from -60mV until it reaches a set value, known as the threshold value (-40 to -30mV), it then produces an action potential.

Related Pearl: Resting membrane potential (RMP) in tissues

Tissue

RMP(mV)

Neuron

-70

Skeletal muscle

-90

Myocardial muscle

-90

Smooth muscle

-20 to -65

questions.text: The function of which of the following factors is not screened by the partial thromboplastin time assay?
questions.solution:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test.

The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen.

In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

 Factor VII deficiency 

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

questions.text: Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor occurs via which of these receptors?
questions.solution:
The specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120. 

The drug maraviroc works by inhibiting interactions with the gp120. This is by binding to the CCR5 receptor on the lymphocyte.

Other options:

Option B : Cell fusion occurs via binding to gp41. Cell fusion is essential for infection to take place. Enfuvirtide is the drug that binds gp41, thus preventing viral entry. 

Option C, D: Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of a co-receptor CXCR 4 for T cell tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: Bubonocele is a type of _________.
questions.solution:
Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal.

Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal development.

Related Pearl: Types of indirect inguinal hernia

  • Bubonocele – Hernia limited to the inguinal canal.
  • Funicular – Hernia stops just above the testis.
  • Complete/scrotal – Hernia reaches bottom of scrotum.

questions.text: A newspaper editor discloses the identity of a victim of rape without prior permission. He would be tried under which of the following sections?
questions.solution:
Section 72 of BNS (IPC Section 228A) deals with punishment for disclosure of the identity of the victim of rape.

Other options:

Option A: Section 71 BNS (IPC 376E) deals with repeat offenders.

Option C: Section 73 BNS (IPC 228A (3)) deals with printing or publishing any matter relating to court proceedings without permission.

Option D: Section 74 BNS (IPC 354) deals with the assault or use of criminal force on a woman with intent to outrage her modesty.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 10 years which may extend to imprisonment for life.

65(1) Persons committing the offence of rape on a woman under16 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life. 376
66 The person committing an offense of rape and inflicting injury which causes death or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state. Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years may extend to imprisonment for life or with death. 376A
65(2) The person committing an offense of rape on a woman under 12 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years but which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine or with death 376AB
67 Sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife during separation, without her consent Imprisonment for not less than 2 years but which may extend to 7 years and with a fine. 376B
68 Sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) who induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place, or institution to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape. Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and with a fine. 376C
70(1) Gang Rape Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine 376D
70(2) Gang rape on a woman under 18 years of age Rigorous imprisonment for life and with fine 376DA
71 Repeat offenders Imprisonment for life or with death 376E
74 Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty Imprisonment for not less than one year, extending up to five years and with fine. 354

 

As per the The Gazette of India, from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Document 2023

questions.text: Which of the following organs is tested in Breslau’s second life test?
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, also known as the stomach bowel test, the stomach and the duodenum are tested.

This test is done to determine whether the baby was born alive or not.

It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live-born child. Detecting the presence of this air in these viscera constitutes the basis for this test.

Procedure :

The stomach and duodenum are removed separately and placed in water. If they float, make a small cut while underwater to see air bubbles coming up. A floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test.

Interpretation:

  • A positive test proves live birth even in the absence of a positive hydrostatic lung test. This may happen if there had been some obstruction in the respiratory passages.
  • A negative test does not mean stillbirth since air does not necessarily enter the stomach in adequate amounts during the breathing act.
  • Putrefaction invalidates the result.

Note: Breslau’s first life test is when the same test is performed on the lungs. Also known as Hydrostatic test/ Floatation test / Raygat’s test.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding nodular scabies?

choices.text: Presents as violaceous nodules in the groin, penis and scrotum
Represents a hypersensitivity reaction to mite antigens

questions.solution:
Nodular scabies is an atypical presentation of scabies. It is highly pruritic.

It presents as a few violaceous, pruritic nodules are often localized on the groin, axillae and male genitalia. They represent a hypersensitivity reaction to mite antigens. These nodules persist for weeks or months after anti scabies treatment.

The image below shows nodular scabies.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient is being evaluated for longstanding anemia. On clinical examination, you notice the given finding. Which of the following metal poisoning is associated with this characteristic finding?
questions.solution:
The image is showing characteristic Burtonian lines, which are seen in lead poisoning and mercury poisoning.

These are bluish-grey gingival lead lines that occur with chronic exposure to lead poisoning.

The image given below shows Burtonian lines on the gums.

questions.text: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is most commonly caused by the mutation of genes encoding which of the following ion channels?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is most commonly caused by the mutation of the genes encoding calcium channels (CALCL1A3).

It is an autosomal dominant ion channel myopathy with an onset in adolescence. Males are usually affected more than females. It presents as proximal muscle weakness. Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be involved. 

The diagnosis is established by a low serum potassium level during an attack, after excluding secondary causes.

Ion channel myopathies include the following:

Ion channel affected Manifestation
CALCL1A3 Hypokalemic periodic paralysis 
KCNJ2

Andersen–Twail syndrome

  • Autosomal disorder
  • Periodic paralysis, heart arrhythmias, and skeletal abnormalities
SCN4A Myotonia and periodic paralysis
CLC1 Myotonia congenita
RYR1

Congenital myopathy (central core disease)

Malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the hernia sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

Option A: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Petersen hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon, and the retroperitoneum, after any type of gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: What is Lynch syndrome also known as?
questions.solution: Lynch syndrome is also known as hereditary non-polyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It accounts for 2% of all colorectal cancers. It is characterized by autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, such as hMLH1, hMSH2, hMSH6, PMS1, and PMS2, leading to microsatellite instability.

questions.text: Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by ________
questions.solution:
Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by the rubella virus.

The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataracts, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions is referred to as expanded rubella syndrome. The thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term blueberry muffin syndrome. 

While the blueberry muffin syndrome is characteristically caused by rubella, the blueberry muffin-like hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions may also be seen in the case of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

The following image shows blueberry syndrome:

Other options: Maternal varicella occurring close to delivery may cause congenital varicella syndrome in babies in the first 2 weeks of life. This presents as a serious disseminated disease with a risk of encephalitis and pneumonia.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A patient having chronic otitis media with perforation of pars tensa is scheduled for myringoplasty to restore hearing. Which of the following is true regarding the techniques used here?

choices.text: In underlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In underlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
In overlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In overlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus

questions.solution:
In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both techniques.

Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.

questions.text: During your posting in the infertility clinic, you notice the following instrument. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is Rubin's cannula.

It is used while performing a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). The cone prevents the retrograde spillage of the dye into the vagina, while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity. This investigation is performed to study tubal patency in women.

Another cannula that can be used to perform HSG is Spackman cannula. It allows for the intra-operative manipulation of both anteverted and retroverted uterus.

questions.text: Please choose the correct location of blood vessels in a trachomatous pannus.

choices.text: Between Bowman’s membrane and substantia propria

questions.solution:
The vessels in the trachomatous pannus are superficial and lie between Bowman’s membrane and epithelium.

Trachomatous pannus develops in the superior limbus as a lymphoid infiltration and vascularization.  Pannus in trachoma is progressive—infiltration occurs ahead of vascularization.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive from the picture:
questions.solution:
Vaginal sponges are barrier methods of contraceptive which are saturated with 1000mg of spermicide usually nonoxynol-9.

Female condoms are also barrier methods and have the added benefit of STD prevention.

Vaginal diaphragms are also called Dutch caps and are always used alongside a spermicidal jelly.

Vaginal rings usually contain levonorgestrel and it is absorbed slowly through the vaginal mucosa.

questions.text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination, stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function

Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wall
  • Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis. 
  • Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment 
  • Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Family participatory care guidelines, released by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, refers to ______

choices.text: Participation of families in community health camps
Family participation for improving newborn health
Family participation for rehabilitation of member with disability

questions.solution:
• Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has released Operational Guidelines for Planning and Implementation of Family Participatory Care (FPC) for improving newborn health.
  • FPC provides for partnership between health care staff and families for care of sick newborn.
  • Under FPC, the capacities of parents-attendants are built in newborn care through a structured training programme (audio -visual module and a training guide).
  • The staff at newborn care unit will provide continuous supervision and support.
  • Provisions for infrastructure and logistics strengthening required for implementing FPC are ensured in the annual state Program Implementation Plan (PIP).
  • In this regard, FPC has emerged as an important concept of health care which provides for partnership between health care staff and families in care of sick newborn admitted in the NICU. The move is expected to bring down infant mortality.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with congenital scoliosis is found to have hemivertebrae. The affected structures are derivatives of which layer of the mesoderm?
questions.solution:
The vertebrae are derived from somites which are derivatives of paraxial mesoderm. The paraxial mesoderm during development gets organized into segments called somitomeres and somites.

Somitomeres appear in the head region of the embryo. They are rounded structures and 7 in number. They form the mesoderm and muscles of the head and jaw. 

From the occipital region downwards, somitomeres organize into somites. The first pair of somites arise in the occipital region of the embryo at approximately the 20th day of development. From here, new somites appear in craniocaudal sequence at a rate of approximately 3 pairs per day.

By the end of the 5th week, 42-44 pairs of somites are present. There are 4 occipital, 8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, and 8 to 10 coccygeal pairs. The first occipital and the last five to seven coccygeal somites later disappear. The remaining somites form the axial skeleton.

questions.text: What is the most common neoplasm of the appendix ?
questions.solution:
The most common neoplasm primarily identified in the appendix are carcinoid tumors. 

They account for approximately 66% of all tumors of the appendix. They are detected in 0.3 to 0.9% of appendectomy specimens.

Adenocarcinoma of the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers. The adenocarcinoma malignancies are three subtypes:

  • Mucinous
  • Colonic type 
  • Adenocarcinoid

Mucinous is the most common subtype whereas Adenocarcinoid is the rarest.

Related Pearl: Appendicular tumors and their characteristics

Appendicular tumor

Characteristics

Carcinoid

10 times more common than any other tumor of appendix

Goblet cell carcinoid tumor

More aggressive

Endocrine and glandular differentiation

Primary adenocarcinoma

Usually of mucinous type

Mucinous cystadenoma

Can present as pseudomyxoma peritonei

questions.text: A 25-year-old model who is on top of her game comes to get liposuction done. She says she is obese and would like to get rid of the "flabby tissue". On inquiry, it is revealed that she eats high-calorie food multiple times a month and regrets it afterward. She also sometimes skips meals. On examination, BMI is 23, and the finding shown below is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows calluses and pigmentation on knuckles, known as Russell's sign. The given clinical history of binge-eating, body-image issues, Russell's sign along with a normal BMI is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

The calluses on hands form due to the repeated scraping of knuckles on the teeth, during self-induced vomiting.

Bulimia can be differentiated from anorexia nervosa by the following features:

  • The body weight is within the normal range.
  • Bulimia is seen in older age groups (late adolescents or adults).
  • Any peculiar eating habit (like dividing food into small portions) is not seen.
  • Amenorrhoea is not common.
  • Psychiatric symptoms such as depression are more common.

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders- fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders- carbamazepine

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the casualty after overdosing on anti-hypertensive medication. On examination, there are multiple cuts on her wrists. On further inquiry, her father says she has marked fluctuations in her mood with a history of unstable relationships and previous suicide attempts. What is the main defense mechanism used by these patients?
questions.solution:
The given history of repetitive self-destructive acts, unstable relationships and mood swings point towards a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder. The main defense mechanism such patients use is splitting i.e., distorting interpersonal relationships by considering each person to be either completely good or bad, with no middle ground.

Borderline personality disorder is classified under cluster B. It is characterized by an unstable affect, mood swings, marked impulsivity, unstable relationships, recurrent suicidal behavior, chronic feelings of emptiness or boredom, identity disturbance, and inappropriate anger. If stressed, the patient may become psychotic.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of which of the following stimulants?
questions.solution:
Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of secretin.

Secretin is secreted by the S cells of the duodenum. Its primary function is to promote the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum. This secretion is poor in enzymes.

Other functions:

  • Augments the effects of CCK
  • Inhibits gastrin release
  • Decreases gastric acid secretion
  • Contraction of the pyloric sphincter
  • Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the staffing at urban primary health centers?
questions.solution:
An urban primary health center will cover 50,000-60,000 population and will be staffed with:

  • Two doctors (one regular and one on a part-time basis) 
  • 3 staff nurses
  • 1 pharmacist
  • 1 lab technician
  • 1 lady health visitor
  • 4–5 ANMs (depending upon the population covered)
  • Other clerical and support staff and one program manager

Basic functions provided are:

  • OPD
  • Basic lab diagnosis
  • Drug/contraceptive dispensing
  • Health education along with referral services

*Note: The above data is according to IPHS 2017 guidelines. The revised guidelines as per IPHS 2022 have been listed in the pearl attached below.

International Nurses Day is an international day observed around the world on 12 May of each year, to mark the contributions that nurses make to society.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: +4 beds Desirable: +4 daycare beds Desirable: +4 beds

Note: The desirable will be over and above the essential beds.

The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases
  8. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems
  9. Basic Oral Health Care
  10. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  11. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27
